title: Debate on Solid Practitioners Strategy and Monetization Ethics
summary: The group debated a proposal regarding "Value Generation and Monetization Strategies" for Solid Practitioners, balancing the need for economic sustainability (to drive adoption) with core community values opposing data privatization and exploitation, referencing the WarmShowers failure.

messages.body: As an experiment, I drafted this Proposal + Notes  from our first meeting with the help of the _Solid GPT agent_ hoping this might be useful. Would love to know your thoughts ðŸ˜‹

> <@danielbakas:matrix.org> sent a file.

The proposal sounds very executively ðŸ˜Ž. I am personally not very good at following the paths, and especially the perspective of being measured in any way makes me feel rather uncomfortable, but it's probably more a different operations mode then anything else, not necessarily incompatible with yours (hopefully!). 

I have a comment to _Value Generation and Monetization Strategies_

As mentioned earlier, I was a contributor to the community built WarmShowers Android app. Out of the "users base" built with this app, WarmShowers LLC was created - on stolen intellectual property (of volunteers from the community who contributed their time, skills and ideas) and privatised community data.

With Solid we hope to bring the ownership back to the community. We'd like to build open standards that every app in the domain can integrate with and help the community grow together, in a non-competitive way.

We don't want anyone any more to take advantage of our community and extract value out of it. We'd like to cultivate sustainable community that brings value to its members outside of any businesses models and monetization strategies. 

Would this profile fit in the strategy for Solid Practitioners?

I believe there is no search for **the** strategy. When it comes to value generation and financial (or broader economic) sustainability there is a place and need for pluralism.
What you are saying sounds really great to me. Would you be open to sharing some details on how you plan for the community that benefits from the value you generate to support your work and incorporate some form of reciprocity?
BTW some years ago I was actively participating in designing https://www.valueflo.ws/ which aims to be generic enough to describe any approach that people would like to practice. Not sure how close it currently is to that goal but if anyone is interested to try and describe their approaches I would be interested in testing it out.

> Would you be open to sharing some details on how you plan for the community that benefits from the value you generate to support your work and incorporate some form of reciprocity?

Sure, it's nothing particularly special, just being transparent about the costs. We got founding from nlNet earlier and plan to apply again soon. With that we should probably establish some "salaries" or hourly-rate for contributing and then gradually transition from external founding to community support to cover the operations. If we bring enough value for the community, it will collectively strive to cover our needs so that we keep providing the value. From WS financial reports the community has enough capacity to cover our needs with a surplus / pay us decent market rates (which are way above my needs). 
(I did not discuss it with michal/mrkvon very extensively yet)

I don't have anything specific in mind. Grants like ones from NLnet are one option, I also currently work on project arranged with them. Some people use services like https://opencollective.com/
I think we can document all kinds of approaches that different practitioners are using so that everyone can have a good picture of what is available out there.

> <@mariha:matrix.org> The proposal sounds very executively ðŸ˜Ž. I am personally not very good at following the paths, and especially the perspective of being measured in any way makes me feel rather uncomfortable, but it's probably more a different operations mode then anything else, not necessarily incompatible with yours (hopefully!). 
> 
> I have a comment to _Value Generation and Monetization Strategies_
> 
> As mentioned earlier, I was a contributor to the community built WarmShowers Android app. Out of the "users base" built with this app, WarmShowers LLC was created - on stolen intellectual property (of volunteers from the community who contributed their time, skills and ideas) and privatised community data.
> 
> With Solid we hope to bring the ownership back to the community. We'd like to build open standards that every app in the domain can integrate with and help the community grow together, in a non-competitive way.
> 
> We don't want anyone any more to take advantage of our community and extract value out of it. We'd like to cultivate sustainable community that brings value to its members outside of any businesses models and monetization strategies. 
> 
> Would this profile fit in the strategy for Solid Practitioners?

Absolutely mariha! I have personally experienced what "performance metrics" can mean ðŸ˜°
Just some random person following one around to see if one did the job right
I would personally want to get as far away from that as possible, unless absolutely necessary
The aim of this proposal is both to show the value and usefulness of a GPT agent dedicated for Solid, as well as drawing a high level idea of where we would like to start ðŸ¤“
I love that you shared your honest feedback. That's what it's all about ðŸ˜„

I absolutely agree that as Solid Practitioners, we will strive for our community to share the core values and goals we all do, like fairness, giving people back control of their data, and reducing inequality in our communities, and social groups

At the same time, many organizations and businesses that are currently operating under this socio-economic system require, at least, sustaintability. Some even have investors to whom they need to report to, who are expecting profitability

In order for Solid to be adopted globally, I believe we should try to appeal, not only to social and moral values, which Solid is already rooted in, but also to the practical applications it can have, where the majority of businesses and organizations that could implement Solid have asked the same first question when we share Solid with them: "But how is this more valuable to me than what we currently have, specially if there is no clear way on how to make it economically sustainable, let alone profitable?"

The reason we propose that Solid Practitioners work together on defining possible _Value Generation and Monetization Strategies_, is because, that way, we can get ahead of situations like the ones mariha just shared, where individuals with questionable goals and values could try (or have succeeded in) the privatization or immoral monetization of Solid

And instead, by getting ahead, we could shape, seed and grow a different paradigm of sustainability and profitability with Solid, that is not rooted in inequality, injustice or unfairness, but instead (and like mariha says) on community, kindness and fairness ðŸ¤“

The fundamental reason we included a _Value Generation and Monetization Strategies_ section, is because different profiles might be looking for different things in Solid. Some may be individual users looking to store their individual data elsewhere, and some might be big companies, organizations or governments with business or socioeconomic objectives that have local, regional or even a global impact

It would be awesome if we could think about how Solid can become economically sustainable for all profiles, from small to large, given that some might be reluctant to update their whole infrastructure for Solid, if there is no clarity about how it might provide value, become economically sustainable or even allow them to increase profits or reduce costs
Always rooted in the values and goals of Solid we all share ðŸ˜„
Food for thought ðŸ˜‹

I agree with a very broad spectrum of strategies. Personally, I would hope that all the strategies meet two simple requirements:

1. Honesty - no matter what the strategy embraces people who use it openly communicate it
2. Practice - someone at least is trying to put it into practice, even if they 'fail' it is still a valuable experience

Given the above everything could be a fair game

Yes, a multitude of strategies sounds much better (at this point in time). I guess I just don't like when someone sets plans for me, and that proposal made me feel like so \\/(^\_^)\\/
(even though I believe it summarises quite well what we all collectively said at the meeting, and the meeting itself felt a bit fuzzy for me too, so I get the urge to add some structure (it was many people too!)).

I'll try to formulate my objections more clearly next time.

We do have an OC account too: https://opencollective.com/ohn It's great for transparency but we decided to skip it for nlNet founding because of too high (in this case) service fee, with a regrettable loss for transparency. We may consider self-hosting our account in the future. Thanks for bringing it up!
Just wanted to circle back to our chat about the proposal. ðŸ˜… I might have missed the mark in how I presented it
mariha Iâ€™m sorry if it felt like we were overstepping. Not our intention! We were hoping to kickstart our brainstorm from what we all shared last time ðŸ¤—
Weâ€™re all for us shaping this together ðŸ’ªðŸ½

> <@mariha:matrix.org> Yes, a multitude of strategies sounds much better (at this point in time). I guess I just don't like when someone sets plans for me, and that proposal made me feel like so \\/(^\_^)\\/
> (even though I believe it summarises quite well what we all collectively said at the meeting, and the meeting itself felt a bit fuzzy for me too, so I get the urge to add some structure (it was many people too!)).
> 
> I'll try to formulate my objections more clearly next time.

And no worries! That kind of feedback is and will be a vital part of our process! ðŸ˜„
Would love to hear more about everyoneâ€™s thoughts and especially any specific points youâ€™d like to see addressed or included ðŸ¤“
So far a mix of strategies sounds great! ðŸ˜ƒ

As a newbie/observer(?) to Solid community spaces, I am interested more in discussing the usage of Solid and Semantic Web and less any meta-strategies for this group. I hope you don't mind if I cease my participation in this conversation.

Hey mariha! I completely understand and respect your decision. I just want to emphasize that your insights and participation are always valued here. We are still defining clearly our goals and purpose, and we are yet to discover if these strategies are what the group, as a whole, is looking for. Maybe the usage of Solid and the Semantic Web is exactly what this group is looking for since, I believe, we all share our passion for Solid and the Semantic Web ðŸ˜„
If you ever feel like diving back into these discussions, feel free to jump back in ðŸ¤—

> <@danielbakas:matrix.org> sent a file.

In the meantime, and coming back to the purpose of #solid-practitioners:matrix.org, we'd love to continue hearing your thoughts about what we were discussing before, around possible **mixed strategies** that combine **honesty** and **practice** (as per elf-pavlik (elf Pavlik)), the practical usage of Solid and the Semantic web (as per mariha), and of course the content of the proposal (combining multiple areas of interest) ðŸ˜„
A very interesting discussion btw

Well, I'd encourage you to hold your horses and wait until I do as I said I would in the meeting and post a revised README outlining the purpose, scope, and audience of the group.  Once that is online (probably tomorrow), you can all have at it and make suggestions for ammendments.  This chatroom is a good place to bring up general topics, but if we want agreement amongst the group, that has to happen on github where there is a record or what and why we decided.  In general my comment on strategies is that our business is supporting existing projects and to try to develop a strategy for the adoption of Solid is *way* beyond our resources.  It should not be our business to define strategies from above but to help projects that are solving community issues develop the strategies they need to complete their specific projects.
Good to know! The goal of this doc was precisely this one. To bring up an interesting perspective for everyone to share. If that approach is to be had on GitHub, that sounds great ðŸ˜„
I'll post soon.
I think many of the things you've discussed are good long-term goals for the group, but in the short run we should think about what we can actually accomplish nd who it would serve.
Excellent!
This is really interesting! In the spirit of holding our horses, we'll wait for the right time and space to discuss further. Just wanted to mention we agree too ðŸ¤©
And we are excited about this

Thanks for writing this!

In particular this:
> Well, I'd encourage you to hold your horses 

and this:
> It should not be our business to define strategies from above but to help projects that are solving community issues develop the strategies they need to complete their specific projects.

ðŸ’š
ðŸ¤—

title: Background on Hospitality Exchange Communities
summary: Participants provided context on the history and governance issues within hospitality exchange communities like WarmShowers, highlighting the risks of privatization and the founding of OpenHospitalityNetwork.

messages.body: They're separate projects, and we don't have access to warmshowers database. ðŸ™‚ mariha was volunteering in Warmshowers, and founded [OpenHospitalityNetwork](https://openhospitality.network) which sleepy.bike is part of.

WS was built by the community and then privatised. It still exists but has changed very much since the Foundation with a new Board was created. 

I was one of the contributors volunteers to WS Android app when new payed app was released and our API key was revoked access to the server. You can read more in the message we updated the app with: https://warmshowers.bike (it has a short background story).

Michal was one of the main developers of Trustroots.org. We are also in contact with BeWelcome.org team. 

In general hospitality exchange communities face issues with governance one by one. Probably the most spectacular was CouchSurfing.org becoming CouchSurfing.com.

We can maybe tell more at the next meeting.
I don't exclude collaborating with WS in the future though, if they were open to that.

title: Unix Timestamp Milestone Celebration
summary: A brief, off-topic announcement celebrated the Unix Timestamp reaching 1.7 billion.

messages.body:
Hi, reposting from https://matrix.to/#/#solid:converser.eu, maybe you'll appreciate this offtopic ðŸ˜œ

In a couple of hours, there is an important moment for **UNIX Timestamp** that we all use and love ðŸ˜‰

It will reach **1.7 billion** today at **Tue Nov 14 2023 22:13:20 GMT+0000**. ðŸ¥³ðŸŽ‚ðŸŽ‰

This kind of roundness only happens every 3 years or so; 2 billion will come in 2033.

You can watch it e.g. at https://www.unixtimestamp.com/ or make a script or whatnot ðŸ‘€

See when it happens in your local time by running `new Date(1.7 * 10**12).toLocaleString()` in some JavaScript console (e.g. Node or your web browser developer tools) ðŸ™‚

So, get ready to celebrate! ðŸ˜

_note, this is not exactly 1.7 billion seconds since timestamp's inception, because of [leap seconds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leap_second)_
Less than 400 seconds to go! ðŸ˜œ

title: Revised Solid Practitioners Group Scope and Governance
summary: Jeff Zucker announced the publication of a revised GitHub README defining the group's goals and scope, triggering discussion on administrative issues like GitHub watching and future meeting agendas.

messages.body: **Announcement** I've put up a [revised README](https://github.com/solid-contrib/practitioners) defining the goals, audience, and scope of this group.  Please add your thoughts in [the discussion](https://github.com/solid-contrib/practitioners/discussions/1) or, if you have specific wording changes, submit a PR.  If anyone is needs help with github (or matrix, or any of the tools we use), please speak up and I or someone else can probably help.

Not sure how to do this: "Please set yourself as a watcher of the Solid Practitioners Announcements Repo if you wish to be informed of upcoming meetings and events." (Solid Practitioners Announcements is a folder, not a repo, unless I'm missing something.)
I mean, I know how to watch the repo, but not a specific folder. I tried searching, I'm not sure it's possible.
Yeah, I guess I should rephrase that to "set yourself to watch the repo and keep an eye out for PRs to practitioners/announcements/* for new announcements

This is really good, Jeff. Very detailed, clear and focused--like, here's exactly what is in the scope of this group, and what isn't. It's a really good example of how to define what a group is and does--I'm going to try to do that with the Onboarding group.

title: Solid Explainer Content and Onboarding Strategy
summary: Members discussed creating educational content ("Here's how Solid will fix that") and decided to establish a dedicated Solid Onboarding chat room to explain Solid's practical use cases, while also coordinating efforts with the W3C Community Group 'Solid Explainer' initiative.

messages.body:
I just saw a headline, "You hate Youtube ads. But what's the fix?", and I thought, "Well, a decentralized protocol that let people build interoperable apps for sharing videos would be a huge step in the right direction."
And I realized that I have an experience like this every day, if not multiple times a day, where I'll either see a headline, or hear something on the radio or on a podcast, and think, "Solid would fix that." 
Another example: I've heard Cory Doctorow interviewed on several podcasts lately, and on one hand, I'm like, "Yes, exactly!" to all of the problems of platforms that he points out, but on the other hand, I'm like, "How is this guy not talking about Solid?!" It's like someone ranting about the woes of spoiled milk, and never mentioning pasteurization.
Anyway...here's why I bring it up: one of my longer-term hopes for the [Getting Started](https://solid-contrib.github.io/getting-started/) site ( [repo here](https://github.com/solid-contrib/getting-started/) ) is to create a blog, or video channel, or something like that, to post frequent content (or links to externally created content) on one theme: "Here's how Solid will fix that."
And I want to mention it here, because: 1) I'm not sure when I'll be able to get to it, and 2) I think it might be a task that would benefit from several contributors working together--some people have more expertise, and others are better at explaining things, and others at delivering messages in an inspiring way. 

I suppose, rather than just lament that the thing doesn't exist, I should say, if anyone agrees with me, then perhaps we could discuss this as part of the Solid Practitioners group (at a mtg, or here, or in the forum?), or maybe we could try to form a separate group--I'm not an expert on getting things done in groups. Feedback very much wlecome!
I love this. Count me in

@yetanotherjonwilson:matrix.org I totally support establishing a video/podcast and think that the Practitioners group would have content to contribute.  As mentioned in the other channel, I think the first step might be setting up a chat room for your Getting Started work.

I like the idea, and it seems to me that _Solid Practitioners (SP)_ are probably well positioned to describe the real-world-problems that Solid can solve, and people exploring _Getting Started_ resources could be interested to learn from that what SP creates. 

sleepy.bike is a good candidate, I could try to describe our use case for Solid, it's just too many things all at once for me. Maybe we can come back to this idea in some time, Jon Wilson, once we get some steady pace for SP group?

I'll be also happy to collaborate with someone on this, I've been trying to find the right words and terms to describe our situation for quite some time - and my understanding of Solid is still quite limited, despite having based the project on it ;)

It would be actually very helpful for the people who are considering joining our platform/community to explain well for them how is sleepy.bike different then anything they know so far, and especially why is the registration so complicated.

We have some backstory that supports our mission but we also already lost the momentum from within the community and the history alone may be not enough to motivate people to try something new.

messages.body:
I think the idea to collect funding options and possibly add some details, experiences with them would be very helpful. 
We can use this list from the website to start a md file (since I think this list will go under when the site content is reworked) https://github.com/solid/solidproject.org/blob/8a7342e449c236a91114d5d41acfbd6ebf38f443/pages/funding.md?plain=1#L3

We think Solid folks would be a natural fit ;)

Application deadline is December 18, 2023.

Please, let us know if you want to collaborate with us or have ideas who to ask. Thank you!

~mariha, ~michal

title: Challenges of Server-Side Pagination in Solid
summary: Participants discussed the current lack of standardized server-side pagination methods in Solid for handling large datasets like chat logs, noting existing workarounds and limitations regarding document vs. triple level operations.

messages.body:
I don't think I'll be able to attend the next meeting, but I was wondering if anyone knows a good way to do server-side pagination in a solid pod. Our app has a use case where we're trying to implement a messaging/chat system. Since there could be hundreds or thousands of messages, we can't reasonably handle all of them client-side.

Does anyone know of a good way to do server-side pagination?

At the moment, I don't think there is a way. This was being discussed in this issue, but it seems like there hasn't been much activity for a while so I'm not sure about the status: https://github.com/solid/specification/issues/227#issuecomment-773945439

The best thing you can do at the moment, assuming you're talking about paginating documents, is making a request to a container and request the documents in chunks of N per page (doing N parallel requests). If what you meant is paginating triples from a single document, there is no way to do it. If you are able to decide the structure of the documents, you should write data in separated documents instead. For example, for a chat you could have one document per day instead of a document per conversation.

We plan to support pagination soon using the Apache Solr standard kv approach with start=int  and rows=int   where rows is the number of results you want back, and start is the row number you want to start from   https://graphmetrix.com/trinpod

Very interesting. Thanks for the link. This seems to me to put a pretty hard upper limit on the amount of data a solid app can reasonably work with. I'm not sure how well either of those workarounds will scale.

And yeah, Solid's API works on the document level, not the triple level. It seems that generally it's best to store individual triples (or closely related triples that can all define a record) as separate documents in pods.

> <@timbot1789:matrix.org> Very interesting. Thanks for the link. This seems to me to put a pretty hard upper limit on the amount of data a solid app can reasonably work with. I'm not sure how well either of those workarounds will scale.
> 
> And yeah, Solid's API works on the document level, not the triple level. It seems that generally it's best to store individual triples (or closely related triples that can all define a record) as separate documents in pods.

There was also a related discussion to this in the forum: https://forum.solidproject.org/t/post-deleted/6028/3

I see the original post was deleted though, but the blog post is still available on the author's website so I guess it's fine to share it: https://ruben.verborgh.org/blog/2022/12/30/lets-talk-about-pods/

I was replying to timbot1789, it seems like the client I was using didn't support threads nor proper replies ðŸ˜… Sorry about that. I was pointing to this forum thread related with the topic of pagination/documents/etc:  https://forum.solidproject.org/t/post-deleted/6028/4

A group pod has its own webid (which can be granted access to other pods as well as have groups under it) and all in the group can then collaborate - membership is via the vcard:hasMember predicate.  So for the bike effort as well as the smart city effort, groups or organization/sub-organiztion pods can be a good way to organize information and grant access to many members rather than having to copy things around

title: Discussion on Trusted Apps and Authorization Alternatives
summary: The conversation debated the use of acl:trustedApp as a historical workaround for global app access, noting that current server implementations handle authorization differently and mentioning SAI as an alternative direction.

messages.body: Does either Graphmetrix or CSS have a replacement for that?  How do they grant/block global access to things like SolidOS or Penny?  AFAIK, they both just ignore the issue.
Apologies in advance if I'm wrong.
As far as I know CSS grants global access for any app you sign in with. Not sure if there is specification on the way to change this, but I hope there is. Trusted apps was a bad workaround imho
I agree it is a bad work around.  AFAIK, no there is no spec other than trusted-apps being in the WebID-Profile spec
and SAI addresses the issue a different way
TrinPod creates a resource for each trusted app, then gives that resource an authorization to control app capabilities
I was part of suggesting acl:trustedApp some years back, and even then everybody agreed, me included, that it was a bad solution
It's always been meant as an interim solution till we get something better
But things take time =\

title: Proposal for Standardizing Solid-OIDC Provider Metadata
summary: A lengthy discussion occurred regarding the need for standard ways to programmatically retrieve basic definitions, such as labels and icons, from Solid-OIDC providers to improve user experience during login and registration, leading to the creation of a new issue in the Solid-OIDC GitHub repository.

messages.body: Hi again everyone!! I wanted to share an interesting conversation elf-pavlik (elf Pavlik) and I were having over at the #solid/specification room about basic information retrieval of Identity Providers and related agents and classes
Is this the right time and place to share what we discussed? ðŸ¤“
Unless it relates to a library or application being used by one of the projects in this group, the app-development channel might be a better one.

As I understood our conversation, it wasn't about specific app or library. More about offering solid as service, which can include as package or separately:
* hosted solid storages (resource server + authorization server)
* hosted oidc provider
* hosted webids
* hosted (SAI) authorization agent
* hosted various notification related services
And of course hosted solid application(s)
Those are all wonderful things, I  don't see how they relate to the needs of current projects.  This group is for supporting work currently being done, not what might might be done in the future.
I think many of the projects depend on users having many of those services available. Especially if projects wants to focus on providing a solid application.

I recall this comment I made a while ago about on-boarding which starts from an application: https://github.com/solid/solid-oidc/issues/77#issuecomment-654478888

> I see IdP as much higher priority role (especially if it hosts WebID) than any single client application. For that reason I would really hesitate to encourage applications to suggest specific IdP to the user.

The scope of this group is clearly defined : "The focus will be on supporting active projects working on specific products and on "getting things done with what exists" ...  in what way do the topics you suggest meet those criteria?

Now quite elf-pavlik (elf Pavlik). My question was more related to us at Semantyk trying to retrieve the name and logo of Pod Providers to allow the user to select their Pod Provider through a more intuitive and visual interface
We just wanted to know if, when a Pod Provider WebID Document is requested it will contain a standardized label and image for us to use for this interface

I would find it very helpful to gather information on strategies that active projects use for on-boarding new solid users.
Daniel B. do you anticipate that some people would want to use Semantyk without already having all the solid services secured (webid, solid-oidc provider, storage(s) etc.)?
So it is about a specific use case for Semantyk (our project)

> <@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im> I would find it very helpful to gather information on strategies that active projects use for on-boarding new solid users.
> Daniel B. do you anticipate that some people would want to use Semantyk without already having all the solid services secured (webid, solid-oidc provider, storage(s) etc.)?

Security is an issue both for us and for our users
But Iâ€™m not sure wether thats within the scope of this group

> <@danielbakas:matrix.org> We just wanted to know if, when a Pod Provider WebID Document is requested it will contain a standardized label and image for us to use for this interface

Only solid storage provider or/and solid-oidc provider as well ?

> <@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im> Only solid storage provider or/and solid-oidc provider as well ?

Good question. Any provider, I think. We donâ€™t want to limit users
One doesn't login using 'storage provider', on logs in using Solid-OIDC provider, they can be provided by the same org/company or a different ones
AFAIK knowing Storage URI doesn't guarantee any information about who provides the storage
Storage providers may (IMO SHOULD) allow users to use their custom domains
@danielbakas:matrix.org I don't think there is currently any way to programmaticcally get the information you seek
I think it would be helpful to have your user journey written down and catch all the possible nuances
Why do you even care who provides user's storages? They can have some self hosted, some from one provider and more from another

> <@jeff-zucker:matrix.org> @danielbakas:matrix.org I don't think there is currently any way to programmaticcally get the information you seek

I wonder if we should discuss this in the spec channel then. I can think of many instances and examples where apps like Semantyk would want to display a gallery of options for the user to choose to log in from, and having a way that is not manual to retrieve at least the label/name and icon/logo of these options programatically would be very valuable. To users, to developers, and to providers alike

> <@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im> Why do you even care who provides user's storages? They can have some self hosted, some from one provider and more from another

Because there will be popular options and having a visual element instead of having to write down the WebID of the provider is something that weâ€™re interested in
@danielbakas:matrix.org - Do as @elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im suggests - write your use case in github
If you have user's WebID it gives you `solid:oidcIssuer` information to discover their Solid-OIDC providers

> <@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im> I think it would be helpful to have your user journey written down and catch all the possible nuances

This use case is simple:

1. The user enters the app
2. The user wants to log in
3. The user can visualize a gallery of Identity Providers to log in from with label and icon
4. The user selects its desired choice
5. The user logs in with the IdPâ€™s authentication flow
which may have nothing to do with their storage providers, one uses oidc provider to log in not storage provider

> <@jeff-zucker:matrix.org> @danielbakas:matrix.org - Do as @elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im suggests - write your use case in github

Oh ok! ðŸ˜…
Does the user have WebID ?

> <@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im> Does the user have WebID ?

We want them to log in either by providing their WebID or selecting the relevant provider
I can write the use case in GitHub ðŸ¤“
And continue the conversation there
Does it mean that sometimes you want to on-board a new user into solid? They will need to get WebID etc. ?
There is no requirement from Solid-OIDC provider to provide WebIDs

> <@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im> Does it mean that sometimes you want to on-board a new user into solid? They will need to get WebID etc. ?

Yes. So far I was only mentioning login, but registration should have a similar flow

Let's assume user has 1 WebID hosted on webid.example, they can have
* multiple solid-oidc providers oidc.foo.example , oidc.bar.example etc.
* multiple storages data.beep.example , drive.boop.example etc.

Sometimes all those can be provided as one package, which I have impression many people think of when they say *pod*. But user can have their own custom package where each piece comes from a different provider.
I see. That might complicate the flow
Penny offers these options on the â€œConnect your Pod at:â€ window
I can manually input my CSS https://pod.danielbakas.com too
Weâ€™d like to get the labels and logos of these
To show them as an intuitive gallery instead of this dropdown
Those expect Solid-OIDC provider. ID Token provides user's WebID, where one might discover `space:storage` (or not)
Okokok. In that case, I think we are looking for icons and lables of Solid-OICD providers ðŸ¤“
CSS happens to provide solid-oidc provider and storage(s), as well as support hosting webid in the storage, but that is just specific way of deploying it
i have separate CSS which has only OIDC provider and separate which has storage, my web id is hosted via nginx

> <@danielbakas:matrix.org> Yes. So far I was only mentioning login, but registration should have a similar flow

Conformant Solid-OIDC Provider gives no guarantee that it can on-board new user with storage and webid
If you want to support registrations you would probably need to only include providers which do it or send user to a place where they can cherry-pick their services

We (at Semantyk) plan on becoming Solid-OIDC and Storage Providers in the future, and for the short term plan on leaving registration to the user, and expecting them to already know their WebID (by URI) and Solid-OICD Provider (by name/label or logo/icon)
Of course we would love to include registration, but for the proof of concept/prototype, we'll leave it at Login for now
As for the login, we still would love to render that gallery with the icons and labels
For the Solid-OIDC providers
(I think that's what we're looking for at least ðŸ˜…)

I think I understand, you want to have a NASCAR UI https://indieweb.org/NASCAR_problem
You probably will need to hand pick a small number of providers, which means you should be able to just manually pick the icons and labels
Oh wow! I didn't know there was a name for this, much less that it was a problem ðŸ˜‚
Still, do Solid-OIDC providers (like https://login.inrupt.com) have WebIDs, and do those WebIDs resolve to a document that declare an icon and a lable?

That's what we're most interested in, because if there is a standard way in which any Solid-OIDC provider declares at least these two things (label and icon) then we can load as many as we want programatically given their WebIDs

And thus, not only provide the user with more options, choice and freedom (the whole purpose of Solid) but also expanding the possible reach of a Solid-OIDC provider, while also reducing the load for developers
Currently you can only get OIDC metadata which doesn't have that information: https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-discovery-1_0.html#ProviderMetadata
If you assume that user already has WebID and Solid-OIDC Provider do they really need to have a long list to choose it from?
I would look into something like https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Attributes/autocomplete
I wonder if anyone has tried `autocomplete="webid"`

> <@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im> If you assume that user already has WebID and Solid-OIDC Provider do they really need to have a long list to choose it from?

They might now the name of their Solid-OIDC provider, but not the WebID
And they might know their own WebID, but at the same time, people forget their passwords and emails all the time ðŸ˜‚
Real use case, believe me, for the times I've had to help my aunt ðŸ˜‚
Maybe `autocomplete="solid-oidc"`, I haven't used it myself would have to tryt

That can work for an input field, but maybe the options that input field displays are rendered with label and icon, and not the plain WebID of the Solid-OIDC. Or maybe the app (like in our case) prefers visual guides like a ~NASCAR problem~ gallery
The point is, wouldn't it be useful to many to have Solid-OIDC providers declare a label and an icon in a standard way in their WebID documents?
Part of me worries that your approach might be vulnerable to phishing
That's a good point actually
Hand picked NASCAR UI should be save but if you auto generate long selection this is a different story

I see your security concern. And I totally agree with it. But what would be the difference between hand picking logos and labels for each of the hand picked WebIDs, and just hand picking the WebIDs and retrieving the logos and labels programatically?
In principle no difference, in practice I assume that you want to automate it to handle longer list, which might (doesn't have to) lead to a lower barrier to get on that list.

Good. In that sense, considering that for now we would focus (for example) on the very carefully hand picked WebIDs for the Solid-OIDC providers from (let's say) Penny, which are all well recognized and trusted, could we then not automate the retrieval of the logo and label if they were standard in the definition of the Solid-OIDC WebID document?
ðŸ¤“

I don't mean to push, we're just interested in breaking a small but meaningful barrier for developers when they want to render the icon and label of the user's preferred Solid-OIDC provider for their user experience
Maybe not even a gallery, but part of the user profile, where there's a section called "Solid-OIDC provider" where the user can see the icon and label of their provider

> <@jeff-zucker:matrix.org> The scope of this group is clearly defined : "The focus will be on supporting active projects working on specific products and on "getting things done with what exists" ...  in what way do the topics you suggest meet those criteria?

Not with what exists ðŸ˜†  If you like please create issue in https://github.com/solid/solid-oidc but I wouldn't recommend you holding back with any work on Semantyk waiting to get it in the spec and even less into deployed providers.
If we use this example, we would need to hand pick the logo and label for every provider, for every user

> <@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im> Not with what exists ðŸ˜†  If you like please create issue in https://github.com/solid/solid-oidc but I wouldn't recommend you holding back with any work on Semantyk waiting to get it in the spec and even less into deployed providers.

Nice
It's a _would like to have_ not so much a _must_ or _should_ have for us
Yet... ðŸ«£
Haha
I'll create the issue ðŸ¤“
You can still create a hand curated list which Penny, Semantyk and anyone else interested could reuse...

> <@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im> You can still create a hand curated list which Penny, Semantyk and anyone else interested could reuse...

That would be absolutely phenomenal though
I think this could go into https://github.com/solid-contrib
To have a community trusted list
Of Solid-OIDC providers
Where each declare some basic info in their WebID documents about their service
And that would make the list more secure
Possibly

> <@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im> Not with what exists ðŸ˜†  If you like please create issue in https://github.com/solid/solid-oidc but I wouldn't recommend you holding back with any work on Semantyk waiting to get it in the spec and even less into deployed providers.

How about I create the issue about the logo and label in here and see where that leads us? ðŸ¤“
Please go ahead, no matter how long it takes it's worth capturing it.
Thank you elf-pavlik (elf Pavlik)!!
Done!! Created a new issue at [solid-oidc#227](https://github.com/solid/solid-oidc/issues/227)

I expanded the scope of the issue from "label and icon" to "basic definitions" since many Solid apps could be looking for more than just label and icon, and to consider it from the beginning could be useful
ðŸ¤“

This might seem like a very trivial issue, but since we envision Semantyk as a user-centric user-experience-driven platform, we want to have the chance to provide the users with the best UX possible, and that starts at login and registration ðŸ¤—

title: Standardizing Pod Provider WebID Document Information
summary: The discussion centered on whether a standardized label and image should be included when requesting a Pod Provider's WebID Document to improve user interface consistency.

messages.body:
> <@danielbakas:matrix.org> We just wanted to know if, when a Pod Provider WebID Document is requested it will contain a standardized label and image for us to use for this interface

Thats a great idea.  We'll happily follow any standard for that
Thank you for the support gibsonf1 (Fred Gibson)! Would mean a lot if you shared your thoughts on [the issue](https://github.com/solid/solid-oidc/issues/227) ðŸ¤“ðŸ˜‹
That looks like a file in a pod, rather than a group pod with its own webid.  Also all the group members are shown publicly (which might be fine in your case)

title: User Profile, PII Handling, and Access Control UX for Solid Applications
summary: Users discussed effective naming conventions for data storage (WebID Profile vs. App Profile) and the necessity of clearly communicating three levels of data access (public, private, shared) to non-technical users, specifically referencing PII data related to government services and concepts from SAI (Solid Application Interoperability).

messages.body: How are people handling the UI for web ID and App settings in their apps? We're talking about this in our app discussions, and we're not sure how best to communicate the distinctions between web ID data, app settings, and other app data to new users.  Simply referring to it as a "web ID" seems a bit heavy on engineering, and may be confusing to users that aren't web developers.
Do you mean the UI for the user profile and otoh UI for user/app settings?

Well, more like what are people naming these things. Our app needs to build its own profile of private data separate from the web ID, and we're trying to find names for these things that will make sense to users. Calling everything a "profile" will probably get confusing.

I see what you mean. Weâ€™re thinking about this in terms of what the user must know.

For us at Semantyk, the user should only be concerned with wether their data is public or private.â€¨â€¨We believe in simplicity, so for us there is only one profile, the user profile. This profile can have public or private sections, but itâ€™s all part of the same profile.â€¨â€¨As for the system/app preferences, do you have any use cases where the preferences should be public? We manage all preferences and personalization as private data.â€¨â€¨Finally we store everything, including app stuff, in the users pod. We donâ€™t store anything about the user on a system/app pod just yet.

If you need to separate the appâ€™s profile, from the WebID profile, we would call it just that:

The **WebID (or Public) Profile** (public and available at the WebID Profile document)

And the **App (or Private) Profile(s)** (private, available where the app specifies, preferably in the userâ€™s pod)
Is this useful?

> <@timbot1789:matrix.org> Well, more like what are people naming these things. Our app needs to build its own profile of private data separate from the web ID, and we're trying to find names for these things that will make sense to users. Calling everything a "profile" will probably get confusing.

Could you give some examples of such app specific data?
I always like to keep in mind 2 principles:
1. User always can always switch to another app
2. Different users can use different apps and still collaborate
When the user decides to switch to another app, will the data specific to your app become useless for them and they should just delete it as they revoke any authorizations they gave to your app?

I could think of something like 'UI theme', which app provider expects to stay in sync across devices, if we talk about such app specific configuration, would a single resource assigned to the app and only accessible by that app suffice? As app access gets revoked user would have option to have that cleaned up as well.

The data in particular is PII related to receiving government services. And indeed our goal here is to make it shareable with other apps. Perhaps "app specific" isn't the right term. Perhaps "domain specific" is better. However, since this data is PII, we need to communicate the user "data stored here should be kept confidential" vs the web ID where it's always public and shouldn't contain confidential information.

The data in particular is PII related to receiving government services. And indeed our goal here is to make it shareable with other apps. Perhaps "app specific" isn't the right term. Perhaps "domain specific" is better. However, since this data is PII, we need to communicate the user "data stored in this profile should be kept confidential" vs the web ID where it's always public and shouldn't contain confidential information. We're trying to figure out a way to make that clear to them. "Private" seems a little confusing too, because that sometimes means "only the owner can access it." That isn't the case here. The data should be shared, but only with specific people.
From SAI perspective that sounds like a Data Instance in a specific [Data Registration](https://solid.github.io/data-interoperability-panel/specification/#data-registration)

In principle all data should start as only accessible by the user (and their authorization agent). And needs to have an explicit policy set by the user to make it accessible by any other party, including the broad public.

I would find it interesting to read more details about your specific use case. Thinking about defining a shape tree that would be used for the data registration, maybe it could include a that authorization agent shouldn't create access policies that apply to the whole registration but always use `interop:SelectedInstances` scope. Again it's is hard to tell without knowing the exact use case.

> <@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im> From SAI perspective that sounds like a Data Instance in a specific [Data Registration](https://solid.github.io/data-interoperability-panel/specification/#data-registration)

Oh this is cool. We haven't been using this. It doesn't solve how to communicate the purpose of the data to a non-technical end user, but maybe working with it will help clarify our ideas.

Next Tuesday we plan special topic meeting to focus on dedicated party that is responsible for authorization https://github.com/solid/specification/discussions/603
If you could point me to your use case, we could possibly take it as one of the examples that should be addressed.

> The data in particular is PII related to receiving government services.

This suggests to me that not only the kind - shape(tree) - might be relevant, but also which party issued/created that data or is the intended audience of that data. I'm wondering if there is a case where the user would need make their access policy choices not only on the type of data but what kind of government entity it is related to.

In SAI there is also access based on [Inherited](https://solid.github.io/data-interoperability-panel/specification/#scope-inherited) scope. Common example in the primers is some project and all tasks of that project.
In similar way specific interaction with a government service could be created and have various associated resources/documents which are made accessible through their relation to that higher level interaction.

I'm working on an open source project called PASS. We have an intro section on our wiki (although the feature list is a bit dated):
https://github.com/codeforpdx/PASS/wiki/Introduction#overview-of-pass

The goal of the project is to make it easier for people to share data that can help them get government housing services with different government offices. Since our target demographic is non-technical, we're spending a lot of time thinking about how to communicate the security levels of different data in their pod to them.

We're building the data in question using this ontology:
https://hmis-interop.github.io/

I can also recall conversations about tag/label based access policies. For example data could be tagged `IRS`, `DMV` etc. and one could authorize app (or another agent) to access all `IRS` tagged resources, which would not apply to resources only tagged `DMV`. This could work if kind of data could be common across those two contexts and the user can't only rely on the kind of the data they set access policy to.
I think *Case* could act as a higher level construct. From there various documents could be shared using *inherited* access.
Unless the Case is hosted in org storage and various documents on personal storages. Currently in SAI inherited access can only be used  within the same storage.
I would probably need to see some simplified example showing which data goes into whose storage.

Please let me know if you have an example with 
* Organization
* Case manager (or two)
* Client
* Case
* Few document relevant to the case

Especially where each thing gets stored and how all the things relate. For example does the same document gets used in multiple cases with multiple organizations etc.

> For us at Semantyk, the user should only be concerned with whether their data is public or private

Ah this may be the difference in our use case then. For the PASS project we have at least 3 cases:

- The data is public: any agent can access it (e.g. webIDs)
- The data is private: only the user can access it (e.g. app theme settings)
- The data is shared within a limited network: The user has granted some set of permissions to a few people.

The goal of the app is to help people receive civic and welfare services, which requires sharing sensitive data with these servicers.

We want to make sure it's clear to the user what parts of their data is public, what part of their data is private, and what part of their data is shared with the network.

An example of where this could be confusing is with the user's name, which can exist in multiple spaces. The webId may contain a nickname for yourself. It need not be your real name, it can be a pseudonym.

However, for the data we share with civic services, we need to get the person's legal name (otherwise the civic group may not be able to provide services). The rub is that many users will not want to make their legal name public.
Of course, that sounds awesome and makes perfect sense
Still in that case, would you really want to store the shared data in a platform pod?
Iâ€™d be really interested in how you would make shared data work in a decentralized architecture
Weâ€™re looking into that for long-term, but knowing your thoughts would be very interesting

> <@timbot1789:matrix.org> Well, more like what are people naming these things. Our app needs to build its own profile of private data separate from the web ID, and we're trying to find names for these things that will make sense to users. Calling everything a "profile" will probably get confusing.

How about Profile=WebID document (public),  Settings (only you),  Data (only you and those you choose to share it with)

title: TrinPod Group Pod Discovery Mechanism and Privacy
summary: Members discussed how TrinPod handles access to group pods by adding private triples to a user's personal pod for application discovery purposes, while maintaining privacy defaults.

messages.body: mariha:   I've added you to the group.  What we do with trinpod personal pods is add a matching triple in the persons pod who has been added so an app reading your profile will know and be able to list all the pods you have access to.
Thanks for adding me and the explanation! So is the entry in a personal pod for group discovery only?
Yes, we do that so an app (like our trinapp.com) can populate which pods the user can go to

We do keep them as private triples in the webid though, as we do all things by default except what solid needs.  (Then user can add permissions to allow others to see whatever they want in the webid).  So my webid shown above only has these triples visible to the public:  https://frederick.trinpod.us/i
Whereas the actual webid (with full read permission) has 52 triples (states) of info:

title: Defining Shapes and Schema for Products and Services
summary: A new working group was announced to define a common shape for Products and Services, leading to a debate on whether to use 'Project' or 'ProductOrService' as the superclass and how to model organizational relationships.

messages.body: **Anouncement** I have created a [Working Group on Shapes for Products and Services](https://github.com/solid-contrib/practitioners/tree/main/working-groups/shape-for-products-and-services) to discuss a shape we can use to describe our various projects.  Eventually I would like to focus on specifics of  describing community-based and socially oriented products and services. This is a start.
This is beautiful Jeff. Thanks for sharing!

@danielbakas:matrix.org you wrote "Could it be useful for us to first define a basic, shared set of attributes for both, which could in turn contribute to interoperability between products and services?"  -- I am proposing somehing like ProductOrService as a super-class of Product and Service and that super-class would have the shape I proposed which does already address both things.  Or did you mean something else?

Hi Jeff Zucker! Thatâ€™s a good approach. I was proposing â€œProjectâ€ instead of â€œProductOrServiceâ€ but the name is the least important. You got the essence of it. My goal is for us to define a basic shape that can then be extended for specific purposes, like Product or Service ðŸ˜„
That would then allow us to have shared and distinct properties between Product and Service
Well schema:Project is an organization, not a product or service.  doap:Project is sort of  a mixture.
Correct if ProductOrService is the superclass subclasses would be Product and Service and subclass of Product would be SoftwareApplication, etc.
We use the doap approach, where a Project can be an Organization, a Product, a Service or a mix of those
That sounds right
Although if we know for sure that a Project is an Organization, we place it under Organizations instead, as a sub organization of the parent, and then define their Products and Services in Projects
The thing is, sometimes itâ€™s hard to separate Products and Services neatly, and we found it so much easier to just regard them as projects

> <@danielbakas:matrix.org> Although if we know for sure that a Project is an Organization, we place it under Organizations instead, as a sub organization of the parent, and then define their Products and Services in Projects

I find it much cleaner to have a Project being a form of Organization that has members and produces/offers products and services.  That way the ProductOrService description does not have to get involved with things like organizational units, memberships, organization type, etc. those would all be handled in the Organization/Profile resource.
Plus, what happens if Project X goes out of business and Project Y now starts to offer the product or service?
Absolutely. ProductOrService makes perfect sense in that case ðŸ‘ðŸ½

> <@danielbakas:matrix.org> That sounds right

A Project is interesting in that it both has an organization to execute the project and a process with a start and end time in which events take place by the project participants, so we give it two superclasses, process and organization
Thatâ€™s an interesting approach. Thanks gibsonf1 (Fred Gibson)!

title: Search Capabilities in Solid Applications
summary: Members discussed the need for a standardized search API in the Solid specification, sharing examples of existing implementations like the TrinPod /search/ API and SolidOS autocomplete using SPARQL, prompting the scheduling of a future dedicated meeting on the topic.

messages.body: This uses the TrinPod /search/  api which also delivers back the full hierarchy up for both documents to the root container and systems up to the webid so that apps can easily give context and enable users to quickly jump up in the hierarchy.  Would be great to add a search api to the solid spec (I am asking over on specifications channel for it)

we do have [autocomplete field code](https://github.com/SolidOS/solid-ui/blob/main/src/widgets/forms/autocomplete/autocompleteField.ts) by the way for what it is worth, which can call out to public data servers using eg SPARQL #justsayin
That's used for languages, skills, etc in the SolidOS profile editor

**Announcement** I've planned for our February 12th meeting to be on the topic of search.  We'll hear from Trinpod and INRIA about their search efforts, then talk about what each of our project does for search, then draw up a list of our needs, and present that at a joint meeting with the spec writers in the Community Group.

Now that i think about it, one issue with webhook notifications is that CSS implementation drops the subscription after 20 or something days (for memory reasons i think). So one needs to re-subscribe regularly when that happens.
Also, i don't remember exactly, but i think it doesn't give that much detail what has changed.
And last but not least, since everybody can POST to the webhook endpoint, you can't trust that the notification actually came from the server, and may need to verify that the info is valid.

Hopefully the benefits still outweight the issues, i guess you have to try and decide for yourselves. ðŸ¤”

title: Guidance for Building a Solid Career Data Management PoC
summary: A newcomer sought advice for building a Proof of Concept (PoC) for career data management, leading to community recommendations favoring the Community Solid Server (CSS), Javascript/Typescript, and guidance on ontology and interoperability conventions.

messages.body:
**Seeking Collaboration and Guidance for Our Conceptual SOLID-based Project**

Dear SOLID Community,

We are excited to introduce our project, aligned with SOLID's principles, aiming to revolutionise how technical professionals manage their career data. Not only how to manage their personal information but also how this information is shared with others. At the core, we focus on data sovereignty, standardisation, interoperability, and empowering users in data ownership.

Currently in the conceptual phase, we're building a tool for personal data management that integrates data across various technical platforms. Our primary objectives are:

- **Facilitating Personal Data Management**: Creating a unified interface for user data control.
- **Enhancing Data Interoperability**: Ensuring seamless data flow across platforms, adhering to SOLID principles.
- **Promoting User Ownership**: Giving users full control over their digital identities.

In our research, we've engaged with pivotal SOLID repositories like [Soukai Solid](https://github.com/NoelDeMartin/soukai-solid), [Solid Data Modules](https://github.com/solid-contrib/data-modules?tab=readme-ov-file), and [solid-contrib/solid-takeout-import](https://github.com/solid-contrib/solid-takeout-import).

We seek guidance on:

1. **Tool and Technology Adaptation**: Advice on tools and technologies for transitioning to design and implementation.
2. **Collaboration with Projects**: Opportunities to contribute to projects aligned with our vision.
3. **Ontology and Standards**: Insights on using standards like vCard and FOAF for our data model.

As newcomers, we're keen to integrate into the community. We've joined the SOLID forum and Gitter channel and would appreciate guidance on other key forums and their formats.

We look forward to contributing to and collaborating within the SOLID community. Your insights will be invaluable in shaping our project.

Thank you for the warm welcome.

Best regards!

The thing is that for building that proof of concept, we have some doubts related with solid servers and custom ontologies, among other technical stuff.

We have seen that there are several approaches to the solid server (NSS, CSS, ESS, use.id, Trinpod, etc.). Which one better fits our needs for building a PoC? It would be useful at the beginning just implementing a simple flow:

Write to a pod
Read from a pod
Authenticate a user
Which programming language is more supported to develop the whole functional app within the PoC?

When it comes to trying to standardise the way individuals represent their personal career information, we have seen that there exist some ontologies like vcard, foaf or doac. What is the process of enriching those ontologies with our own proposal? At which point in development do you think it may have more importance? How is it the process of creating your own ontology?

Thanks in advance!

For our PoC project, we've had some good success using community solid server. It's installed through node, so easy to send out to dev workstations. It's a no-frills server that seeks only to implement the solid standard, so if you write your code against that, it should (theoretically) work against most of the other servers you listed. It can also be extended with modules, so you can experiment with a nonstandard feature if you feel so inclined.
Javascript definitely has the best support for solid apps. I think there are also a few java libraries floating around as well

Yes! What Tim said. To add to that, regarding choice of ontology you can refer to https://github.com/pdsinterop/conventions. To enrich vcard/foaf/doac with your own proposal, just write your app and then we'll simply document your data format in the conventions (you can PR this yourself) and add your format to the relevant Solid Data Module
To get started, I recommend Inrupt's getting started tutorial https://docs.inrupt.com/developer-tools/javascript/client-libraries/tutorial/getting-started/
I would recommend using JavaScript or Typescript; I've created https://rdfjs.dev/ as an educational tool to help devs understand how you can combine RDF and JS, it might be helpful for you ^_^

Thank you so much for the advice Michiel de Jong (Ponder Source) and Arne. I'll go ahead with the tutorial, also taking into account the https://rdfjs.dev/ resources and then, at vocabulary/ontology definition time I'll keep in mind the potential contribution to the community and the corresponding Solid data modules. I'll keep you updated! Thanks!

> <@timbot1789:matrix.org> Javascript definitely has the best support for solid apps. I think there are also a few java libraries floating around as well

Then I think we'll go with the CSS option + Javascript. Moreover it seems that for the testing side, there are some options that are better aligned with this combination (https://github.com/NoelDeMartin/cypress-solid). Thanks Tim!ðŸ‘ï¸

title: Announcement of Solvent: Native Solid Apps over Filesystem
summary: An announcement was made regarding Solvent, a project enabling Solid applications to run natively over a user's file system using Manas and Tauri.

messages.body:
Hello all. An announcement about [Solvent](https://github.com/manomayam/solvent).

Solvent lets us use Solid apps in native context over filesystem. We can create pod views over  folders, configure root uri for them to be simulated, and run packaged apps over them.

It will thus enable us to code apps against solid storage api with web ui stack, and ship them as native apps against user's file system. The final binaries are very small, (7-15 MB).

It is powered by [Manas](https://github.com/manomayam/manas) for storage abstraction, and Tauri for ui. Can use all sorts of tauri plugins and ecosystem.

Currently SolidOs is packaged, and [binaries](https://github.com/manomayam/solvent/releases/tag/solvent-v0.0.0) are shipped. Request you all to try and provide feedback.

I believe, once the project become stable, this could make Solid an attractive storage api to code web & native apps with single code base. With proper support it can be extended to offer sync solutions, native-first apps, etc in future.

ðŸ™

For short self introduction I can say that I am running small advertisement business in Russia, and that I like to write code in lisps (Racket, Clojure), used them for automation of business operations.
Before this I lived on the border Norway-Russia where took part or initiated several crossborder projects, this or that way related to make information in the area more accessible to its inhabitants, both Russians and Norwegians.
