title: Architectural Design for Federated Geosearch using Community Pods
summary: The sleepy.bike team sought architectural advice on implementing a federated geospatial index, resulting in a community recommendation to utilize dedicated Community Pods for efficient data aggregation, access control, and group governance.

messages.body: I couldn't join the last meeting, but we need to implement an index for geosearch in sleepy.bike. What I was thinking about is probably a federated index (one central index for sleepy.bike members, and there can be other communities with their indexes and they all federate). Is there anyone who'd like to discuss with me / us how to best approach this?
mariha:  Can you explain more about what the geosearch use case is with examples?

We have a map of hosts, where a location of each host is in a different pod. To display them on the map, we iterate on the list of members and make a request to their pod asking about the location.

So we need a geospatial index that will return all points (hosts' locations) in a given range (rectangle area). 

One day, when there are more communities, we may want to display the members of other communities on the same map, so for that we would need a federated (?) index.

michal/mrkvon can probably provide more details.

What if to have a separate community pod which will hold geospatial index for its members and provide this data to the app? 
Thus it would be possible to avoid for app to store spatial indexes in its own store.
But the app, of course, will still query coordinates and build geosp index, dumping data into the corresponded community pods.

The same community pod could be used for various cases, not only for hosting.

For example, local communities on my example: the same people have need to coordinate activities in running. But also with group ordering of sauna or in gathering to play mafia.

These activities could be supported  by different solid apps, but the community pod with various aggregated data, that doesn't belong to particular user - would be only one.

Though, I feel, the notion of community pod can be overcomplication...

A community for us is a list (group) of members who grant access to [some of] their data to other members of the group plus some metadata (like the index).

For the safety of the community, and the people who are part of it, there needs to be some governance of the community and it's assets in place, it's better to name it explicitly because otherwise too bad things can happen. So personally I don't feel like it's an overcomplication, to have a community pod.
I second the idea of using a group pod with its own webid and members to store the locations of members in that one location - then the app can get all locations with a single request.
Also members can have information etc in the group pod that only they can see, chat, etc.

This also supports the idea that members may not always want others to know where they are, so the source of truth location in each members pod can be updated in group pod when member wants it to or not - maybe a sync on and sync off kind of thing
You can also them give all members of that group access to things by simply using that group webid with just one acl

title: Group WebIDs, ACLs, and Private Group Membership
summary: The discussion explored the utility of Group WebIDs versus URIs for access control, particularly addressing the challenge of authorizing access to resources based on private group membership lists (e.g., foaf:Group or vcard:Group) without making the member list public.

messages.body:
I still don't grok how group webId is useful compared to (just) group uri, especially in context when member gives resource access to other members of the group.

It was also mentioned in the past that group webId can allow groups to be non-public, and still be used for access control, and I still don't understand how.

The issue is hinted upon in [CSS#1441](https://github.com/CommunitySolidServer/CommunitySolidServer/issues/1442#issuecomment-1229842295)

Can you elaborate?

if you have a personal pod and make a uri there for a group, it means really the group is all managed out of that personal pod.  If you have a group pod, on the other hand, one or members can control the pod, all the discussions and information and chat among the group can go in that pod, and that group can collaborate with others via their webid

@mariha:matrix.org and @prozion:matrix.org - 
I see  at least two things :

* a specified community (e.g. people registered with SleepyBike)
* a broad, unspecifiable community (e.g. anyone who wants geo data)

My understanding is that SleepyBike is a `doap:Project`, with contributors, maintainers, etc. In a fully Solidified world, it would have a WebID and a pod which would contain at least

* a `vcard:Group` of people with write/merge access to the SleepyBike pod/repo.
* a `vcard:Group` of people registered on the SleepyBike website as hosts.
* a `vcard:Group` of people registered on the SleepyBike website as guests.

The `vcard:Group`s contain WebIDs of their members which are used to provide or deny them access to parts of the pod.
Also, because of our triple level acls, we do not make membership public unless the group wants membership to be public
For example, the group pod I made for the practioners does not make members public at the moment: https://solid-practioners.trinpod.us/i

Thank you for elaborating!

If I want to share a document on my pod with members of such a group via acl:agentGroup, would it work?
You wouldn't need to - anything on the group pod can be readable by the group (and writable too) if you just add an acl at the root with default using the group webid
Oh wait, sorry, yes, you can share with the group that way using the webid from your pod

The issue is, if the member list (foaf:Group) is private, the server performing authorization (for a resource) has no way to fetch that list to check that the authenticated user (who requests the resource) is on it.
(Unless it can send a request authorized as the user, or make some limited query)

How does Trinpod solve this?

I need a few more days to think/discuss internally and possibly answer more properly, but I think the idea to have a separate group for the community administrators (with write access) and the community members is very interesting and seems to me to be a good one. Thanks for giving it!

> <@mrkvon:matrix.org> The issue is, if the member list (foaf:Group) is private, the server performing authorization (for a resource) has no way to fetch that list to check that the authenticated user (who requests the resource) is on it.
> (Unless it can send a request authorized as the user, or make some limited query)
> 
> How does Trinpod solve this?

Solid does not divide the world into "public" and "private" - there is a space in between for shared resources.  If the WebID profile of the organization has rdfs:seeAlso links to group lists A, B, and C, and permissions them so that only members of A can read A and only members of B can read B, they are at least private from members not in the group.  It's true that if you want each member to have access without other members of that group knowing they are a member, there is no easy solution I am aware of.

title: Solid Data Indexing Strategies and Standardization
summary: The group discussed various indexing mechanisms, including the solid:privateLabelIndex for full-text search in PodOS, and debated whether granular property indexing should be integrated into or standardized alongside the existing Type Index specification, concluding that a separate, complementary spec is needed.

messages.body: I could not attend the last meeting, but regarding the search topic I want to make you aware of the  full text search in PodOS using a label index and local search via lunrjs
See https://github.com/pod-os/PodOS/blob/main/docs/features/full-text-search.md
The term solid:privateLabelIndex has become part of the vocab meanwhile
https://www.w3.org/ns/solid/terms#privateLabelIndex

> <@aveltens:matrix.org> The term solid:privateLabelIndex has become part of the vocab meanwhile 

can you explain what a private label index is and how it would be used?
I tried to explain it in the document I linked, can you specify your question? I am happy to elaborate more on unclear points
An application can load it to get all the relevant labels of things in a pod and then search through them
Without loading every document in a pod first

> <@aveltens:matrix.org> I tried to explain it in the document I linked, can you specify your question? I am happy to elaborate more on unclear points

Sorry, if the document you linked to means the one on search,  I hope to have time to look at it later, the definition in solid-terms didn't really tell me anything.  What you just wrote above is a great summary and tells me a lot.  Is there a reason it isn't given in the vocab itself?
No particular reason, I just kept it short and similar to the other descriptions, but I see that this is not enough to understand. There should also be a spec document describing it.

> <@michielbdejong-54c0fe29db8155e6700ef12e:gitter.im> Is there anything from Practitioners that we need to put on the CG call agenda for Wednesday? Any new user stories / feature requests / shortcoming of the specs you identified?

You might mention that four of the Practitioners spoke at Solid World and that I put up the CG URL and mentioned that there were new chairs and regular meetings as well as exciting special topic meetings, also put up the Data-Modules URL and promoted that as well.  The last practitioners meeting was about search/indexing, we're going to discuss it next meeting and then have a joint meeting with the CG.  Maybe on one of your special topic days in March?
Maybe share the URL for the video of our search meeting : https://solid-practioners.trinpod.us/node/t_g2
@michielbdejong-54c0fe29db8155e6700ef12e:gitter.im ^^

Great thanks! I'll watch the video. Maxime also did a demo at this CG call, let's hope some of this work can consolidate into client-client specs that describe how "Search Indexes for Solid" can work!

> <@michielbdejong-54c0fe29db8155e6700ef12e:gitter.im> Great thanks! I'll watch the video. Maxime also did a demo at this CG call, let's hope some of this work can consolidate into client-client specs that describe how "Search Indexes for Solid" can work!

There are several threads of discussion in the Practitioners that could lead to several different specs.  I think the indexing that @lecoqlibre-5c1b5e25d73408ce4fb27c24:gitter.im is working on is super important and should be easy to integrate into the type-indexes spec.  A second thread is related to search interface - what sort of query string should it expect.  That would be a harder sell since it requires the server to do things but it needs discussing.

> <@jeff-zucker:matrix.org> There are several threads of discussion in the Practitioners that could lead to several different specs.  I think the indexing that @lecoqlibre-5c1b5e25d73408ce4fb27c24:gitter.im is working on is super important and should be easy to integrate into the type-indexes spec.  A second thread is related to search interface - what sort of query string should it expect.  That would be a harder sell since it requires the server to do things but it needs discussing.

I'm wondering if we should not instead propose a spec next to the type-indexes spec. Indeed, we are working on a mechanism to index any property of the resources (not only the type).

The Type Index (TI) is designed AFAIK to index "big things" like Tim Berners-Lee said once if I remember correctly. In my understanding TI is more oriented on data discovery of first level kind of things and can also serve to discover the "entry points" of applications. TI is intended to be shared by applications evolving in business domains which could be different (a contact app, a photo app, a chat app, etc) so TI is "horizontal" or cross-domain.

The indexes I demoed are used by applications evolving in the same business domain (following the same client-client standard). They should be used "vertically". Theses indexes are also not limited to index only "big things" but are more granular and could be used for whatever the applications need to index.

In other words I would say the two kinds of index previously mentioned are in fact complementary. Applications can use both (and probably at least TI in many cases). Even if we can use the demoed indexes vocabulary to replace some part of the current TI, I would say that we still need a TI spec to keep a dedicated simple cross-domain data discovery mechanism. Then we can perhaps write a separated spec to define a "standard" way to index things for vertical use.

I'd like to hear more.  I guess the way I look at it is that we can create a type for anything and get as specific as we want.  We can have an index pointed to from schema:Photo and also one to ex:RadiologicImages.

> <@jeff-zucker:matrix.org> I'd like to hear more.  I guess the way I look at it is that we can create a type for anything and get as specific as we want.  We can have an index pointed to from schema:Photo and also one to ex:RadiologicImages.

Are you saying that we could have something like this:
```
<#ab09fd> a solid:TypeRegistration;
     solid:forClass schema:Photo;
     solid:instance </link/to/a/Photo/index>.
```

If so, would not it be confusing to have the index type (ex: `ex:Index`) mapped to `schema:Photo`?

> <@lecoqlibre-5c1b5e25d73408ce4fb27c24:gitter.im> I'm wondering if we should not instead propose a spec next to the type-indexes spec. Indeed, we are working on a mechanism to index any property of the resources (not only the type).
> 
> The Type Index (TI) is designed AFAIK to index "big things" like Tim Berners-Lee said once if I remember correctly. In my understanding TI is more oriented on data discovery of first level kind of things and can also serve to discover the "entry points" of applications. TI is intended to be shared by applications evolving in business domains which could be different (a contact app, a photo app, a chat app, etc) so TI is "horizontal" or cross-domain.
> 
> The indexes I demoed are used by applications evolving in the same business domain (following the same client-client standard). They should be used "vertically". Theses indexes are also not limited to index only "big things" but are more granular and could be used for whatever the applications need to index.
> 
> In other words I would say the two kinds of index previously mentioned are in fact complementary. Applications can use both (and probably at least TI in many cases). Even if we can use the demoed indexes vocabulary to replace some part of the current TI, I would say that we still need a TI spec to keep a dedicated simple cross-domain data discovery mechanism. Then we can perhaps write a separated spec to define a "standard" way to index things for vertical use.

Yes, " spec next to the type-indexes spec." sounds right.

Agreed, ` solid:forClass schema:Photo; solid:instance </link/to/a/Photo/index>.` sounds wrong, `solid:forClass schema:PhotoLibrary; solid:instance </link/to/a/Photos/index#this>.` sounds better.  Then the photo library has domain-specfic indexes  by aperture, exposure, date, keywords, say.

> <@timbl-54d26c98db8155e6700f7312:gitter.im> Agreed, ` solid:forClass schema:Photo; solid:instance </link/to/a/Photo/index>.` sounds wrong, `solid:forClass schema:PhotoLibrary; solid:instance </link/to/a/Photos/index#this>.` sounds better.  Then the photo library has domain-specfic indexes  by aperture, exposure, date, keywords, say.

I guess the content of `</link/to/a/Photos/index>` depends on what the `schema:PhotoLibrary` is supposed to be. In your example, the `schema:PhotoLibrary` still point to an index, right?

If the PhotoLibrary is more than an index, the TI could be:
```
<#ab09fd> a solid:TypeRegistration;
     solid:forClass schema:PhotoLibrary;
     solid:instance </link/to/a/PhotoLibrary#this>.
```

The content of the `</link/to/a/PhotoLibrary>` could look like:
```
<> a schema:PhotoLibraryDocument.

<#this> a schema:PhotoLibrary;
    ex:index </link/to/an/aperture/index>, 
             </link/to/an/exposure/index>, 
             </link/to/a/keywords/index>.
```

Then an example of the `</link/to/a/keywords/index>` could be:
```
<> a ex:Index, schema:KeywordsIndex;
    ex:forProperty schema:hasKeyword.

<#1> a ex:PropertyIndexRegistration;
    ex:forValue "sunset";
    ex:instance </link/to/a/sunset/photo.jpg>.
    
<#2> a ex:PropertyIndexRegistration;
    ex:forValue "flower";
    ex:instance </link/to/a/flower/photo.jpg>.
```

title: Solid Hackathon Planning and Format
summary: Participants discussed organizing non-competitive Solid hackathons focused on specific projects like PASS and sleepy.bike, establishing preliminary goals and structure requirements, and reflecting on the competitive nature of such events.

messages.body:
I was thinking about the hackathon idea that was mentioned a few times recently, I myself don't have experience with hackathons but michal/mrkvon was concerned with their competitive nature.

timbot1789 said they would be happy to participate in a hackathon with PASS project. 

I remember a friend of mine from Chicago who co-founded https://www.pieforproviders.com/ project participated in a create-a-thon organised by https://democracylab.org/ who are based in Seattle... what makes me suspect there is possibly better hackathon culture in the US (West coast?) then in Europe, what Michal experienced.

What if we collaboratively made first hackathon dedicated to PASS and then second one to sleepy.bike, and possibly others?
not sure if that's a good place to look for a job, but maybe if there were some sponsors interested in Hackathons, they might also be willing to sponsor development of the project? Just wondering...

@mariha:matrix.org - we can create our non-competitive hackathon.  The next step is for any project that wants to have a hackathon dedicated to their project, to draw up a proposal - what would the goals and tools be?  What Solid issues would be addressed?  What technical problems would need to be solved? Who would lead/mentor?  Who would judge if we decide to have judges?
sounds good, I think we can try to prepare answers to these questions, for the next or two meetings from today.
I guess it's not good to make any generalisations at the level of continents... sorry if I hurt anyone with this. For sure it's untrue for many hackathons both ways.
(speaking for myself only, I keep forgetting that I should not make assumptions about what others will do)

Speaking for myself again - I don't have any issues with competition, algorithmic programming challenges is actually what got me into computer science - I was really obsessed at solving them.

So personally I probably wouldn't mind some competition, a satisfaction from a hard problem being solved is a great reward for me.

> <@mariha:matrix.org> I was thinking about the hackathon idea that was mentioned a few times recently, I myself don't have experience with hackathons but michal/mrkvon was concerned with their competitive nature.
> 
> timbot1789 said they would be happy to participate in a hackathon with PASS project. 
> 
> I remember a friend of mine from Chicago who co-founded https://www.pieforproviders.com/ project participated in a create-a-thon organised by https://democracylab.org/ who are based in Seattle... what makes me suspect there is possibly better hackathon culture in the US (West coast?) then in Europe, what Michal experienced.
> 
> What if we collaboratively made first hackathon dedicated to PASS and then second one to sleepy.bike, and possibly others?

I am a bit confused with my recent interactions, and I might have confused people with indirect communication when joining the room. Usually I communicate very directly, and with the message above I didn't want to say that I have anything against Inrupt hackathons (just in case it was understood like this).

sleepy.bike won one of them, but as I remember I didn't participate in the hackathon activities except making the explainer / demo, so it's hard to say that I have any experiences, good or bad... I was happy for our three-people team at the time that we won ðŸŽ‰.

I am also confusing speaking for myself as an individual (first part of this and the above message) and speaking as a project representative (second part of this and the above message). We haven't figured it out internally in the project what is our structure or outside communication style, what came out recently in the context of the presentation, and we are doing it right now (mostly internally). 

Thanks for your understanding.

I haven't mention Hadrian in the first message because I don't know what is his handle. At the same time, speaking as an individual, I'll be very happy to explore and experience different hackathon formats.

Speaking for me, I just have some interest to learn about hackathons more, as I never participated in them before. It's hard to imagine how I could be useful in coding process in the popular stacks, but maybe can do something in Clojure. Hm, would be interesting...

Yes, I think hackathons are a great way to find solutions to some of the hardest problems of Solid, as they create an opportunity to connect owners of both (problems and solutions). 

The more diverse the pool of solutions, the better! If something is a thought problem, it is always in the context of popular approaches to it, so a new one needs to be looked for.
There will be a mini hackathon starting on Monday, focusing on using data shapes: https://solidhack.org/

title: Localization Strategy and Tooling (Fluent/Weblate)
summary: The conversation centered on adopting suitable localization workflows for Solid projects, comparing Project Fluent with Vue i18n, discussing platforms like Weblate for managing community contributions, and addressing challenges related to maintaining translation quality.

messages.body:
Hello practitioners ðŸ‘‹ I would like to ask you all about your current and planned workflow for localization. In the UI for my reference implementation of SAI Authorization Agent I went with https://projectfluent.org/ 
Since I use Vue it was very easy thanks to https://fluent-vue.demivan.me/
Now I would like to set up a project on an online platform to accept contributions for other languages, Mozilla has open source project for that https://github.com/mozilla/pontoon
Sadly I couldn't find a public deployment welcoming open source projects, Pontoon has easy deployment to Heroku but it doesn't make sense for me to do it for just one or eventually a handful of projects I plan to work on.
I would like to know how do you manage localization of your projects and if you are still in the planning phase would you be interested in finding a common place to deploy Mozilla's Pontoon, not sure if Solid Project would be open to host it.
As I mentioned during one of the first calls, I see localization crucial to easily adopt open source projects, which are successful in one part of the world, to other parts of the world.
@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im perhaps you could plan to give a brief presentation at the next meeting and gather input there.

Thank you for the suggestion. If there is an interest I could move my usual Monday remote pair-programming session, so that I don't have conflict and can join the practitioners meeting. I will be more than happy to do so!
Next meeting is on the 18th

Trustroots.org that i contribute(d) to, uses hosted.weblate.org which has [free option for FOSS projects](https://weblate.org/en/hosting/).

They also [support Fluent](https://docs.weblate.org/en/latest/formats/fluent.html).

In Trustroots in particular, many community members can -  and do - contribute translations in their native language this way. Weblate has relatively nice and intuitive interface.
Look for this â¬†ï¸ at the bottom of the pricing page.
e.g. https://hosted.weblate.org/projects/trustroots/

I looked at it but didn't see support for Fluent, now I double checked and indeed they do have a beta support for it https://docs.weblate.org/en/latest/formats/fluent.html
So far I was able to import translations from my project, will still need to fiddle with it but so for it looks promising. Thanks a lot michal/mrkvon

> <@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im> Hello practitioners ðŸ‘‹ I would like to ask you all about your current and planned workflow for localization. In the UI for my reference implementation of SAI Authorization Agent I went with https://projectfluent.org/ 
> Since I use Vue it was very easy thanks to https://fluent-vue.demivan.me/
> Now I would like to set up a project on an online platform to accept contributions for other languages, Mozilla has open source project for that https://github.com/mozilla/pontoon
> Sadly I couldn't find a public deployment welcoming open source projects, Pontoon has easy deployment to Heroku but it doesn't make sense for me to do it for just one or eventually a handful of projects I plan to work on.
> I would like to know how do you manage localization of your projects and if you are still in the planning phase would you be interested in finding a common place to deploy Mozilla's Pontoon, not sure if Solid Project would be open to host it.
> As I mentioned during one of the first calls, I see localization crucial to easily adopt open source projects, which are successful in one part of the world, to other parts of the world.

Penny uses Fluent too, and Weblate supports it too and does have a public deployment welcoming open source projects, e.g. https://hosted.weblate.org/projects/penny/ui/

> <@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im> Hello practitioners ðŸ‘‹ I would like to ask you all about your current and planned workflow for localization. In the UI for my reference implementation of SAI Authorization Agent I went with https://projectfluent.org/ 
> Since I use Vue it was very easy thanks to https://fluent-vue.demivan.me/
> Now I would like to set up a project on an online platform to accept contributions for other languages, Mozilla has open source project for that https://github.com/mozilla/pontoon
> Sadly I couldn't find a public deployment welcoming open source projects, Pontoon has easy deployment to Heroku but it doesn't make sense for me to do it for just one or eventually a handful of projects I plan to work on.
> I would like to know how do you manage localization of your projects and if you are still in the planning phase would you be interested in finding a common place to deploy Mozilla's Pontoon, not sure if Solid Project would be open to host it.
> As I mentioned during one of the first calls, I see localization crucial to easily adopt open source projects, which are successful in one part of the world, to other parts of the world.

I agree that localization is very important :). I've only translated my latest app, but I plan to translate others as well. However, I don't have much experience with translations in my own projects and because of what I've seen elsewhere I'm not sure what's the best way to add languages that I don't speak :/.

I don't mean that I'm not sure which tech to use, but how to make sure that the contributions have enough quality and that they won't get abandoned if the application evolves. For now I just linked to this disclaimer for anyone who wants to contribute, but so far I haven't gotten any: https://github.com/NoelDeMartin/umai/blob/main/docs/contribute-translations.md

My guess is that many people capable of contributing great translations will be intimidated with git and editing yaml. That's where tools like weblate come in the picture. On the other hand it's great that you advertise it in the app... :)

Yeah, well I do mention that if anyone doesn't know how to use github they can send me the translations and I'll update the app myself. Though I understand reading that document may discourage some people from contributing rather than encouraging them ðŸ˜… I'm not convinced that something like this will be the final form of how I manage contributions, but I prefer to start like this and automate later on. I prefer not to spend time in hypothetical problems, and if nobody is contributing now I don't think a lot more would contribute if I have a proper platform for translations.
Right, I have no idea if translation UI would help either...
Did you choose https://vue-i18n.intlify.dev/ for a specific reason or just picked the most popular plugin?

> <@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im> Did you choose https://vue-i18n.intlify.dev/ for a specific reason or just picked the most popular plugin?

I chose this one because a Vue developer (Anthony Fu) who's taste I like uses it: https://github.com/antfu/vitesse/tree/main/locales

It also has a nice VSCode integration, etc. But I wouldn't mind changing to something else if there is a good reason for it, right now this one gets the job done and is easy to use.
Thanks, when I was comparing the two I looked at unavoidably biased but reasonable https://fluent-vue.demivan.me/vue-i18n-comparison
This is the post that sealed thte deal for Fluent for me: https://hacks.mozilla.org/2019/04/fluent-1-0-a-localization-system-for-natural-sounding-translations/
Great discussion all! Thanks so much.

(Although there's also work on MessageFormat 2.0, a standardised localisation format that will incorporate the lessons of, among others, Fluent, and should have adapters that ease transition from Fluent (and other systems)
I wasn't able to move my conflicting meeting, still if other participants would like to discuss localization I'm happy to switch between calls for that part.
I'll poll people but I think we can do it at a more convenient time
Are you guys discussing localization?
We will do but probably not today

title: Status of Solid for Production Use
summary: A potential Solid user inquired about the specification's readiness for production environments, receiving affirmative responses conditioned on specific use cases, along with an advertisement for a production-ready server implementation.

messages.body:
Hi there :)

I am considering Solid (or the Solid-spec., not fully firm with the terms yet) for a project of mine. And i was wondering about its status: Is it something one would suggest for production use?

And in case i am in the wrong place here: I'll gladly take an pointers on where to ask the question. ("Practitioners" is what got me ;-)

> <@0ftl:matrix.org> Hi there :)
> 
> I am considering Solid (or the Solid-spec., not fully firm with the terms yet) for a project of mine. And i was wondering about its status: Is it something one would suggest for production use?
> 
> And in case i am in the wrong place here: I'll gladly take an pointers on where to ask the question. ("Practitioners" is what got me ;-)

I think it depends on the use-case, and the biggest issue for "production use" is what your expectations are about user's PODs.

But mostly, yes, I'd say it can be used in production and some people (many of them in this group) are already doing it.

0ftl: We provide trinpod.us and trinpod.eu (easy setup from https://trinapp.com )  Solid servers both designed for massive data (billions of objects in a pod).  We are finishing up an integration with Oracle right now after which we'll finalize solid testing with them.  The services are online now complete with 7 days rolling backup of the data etc.

title: Job Search and Resource Sharing

title: Discussion on Solid Notifications Implementation and Pod Support
summary: The community discussed various notification implementations, specifically mrkvon's experience using webhookChannel2023 versus an independent solution across different Pod providers (CSS and NSS), followed by an invitation to present at the Solid Symposium.

messages.body: Practitioners, if any of you are using notifications in any form I and elf-pavlik (elf Pavlik) would like to hear about it. Thanks!

I tried to use [webhookChannel2023](https://solid.github.io/notifications/webhook-channel-2023) to [watch an inbox and send email notification](https://github.com/openHospitalityNetwork/solid-email-notifications) when something new arrives there (e.g. Activity streams message notification) for sleepy.bike. It worked. But since many current Pods don't support that spec, i ended up implementing [alternative](https://github.com/openHospitalityNetwork/simple-email-notifications) that doesn't depend on notifications spec - the sender has to trigger it. (it also works ðŸ™‚)
What server/POD provider are you using?

Not sure what you're asking. Intention is for sleepy.bike (which is single-page web app written with React) to work with different Pod providers - currently works ok with NSS and CSS. The webhookChannel-dependent implementation of email notification service works well with CSS, but not with NSS. The solid-notification-independent version works fine at least with NSS and CSS.

Both of the mentioned email notification services are dedicated servers written with koa and typescript. They use Solid-OIDC for authentication. I think i wrote some details in both repositories' README, if you want to read more. Or you can ask. ðŸ™‚

I hope this makes some sense, and i can also elaborate if you have specific questions.

I am just trying to understand your use case. Main intention was to see which POD providers you are able to support esp. vis-a-vis notifications (or where majority of  your users are coming from)  because that lets me gauge how useful their current implementation state is in the real world. NSS has no notifications though Alain is exploring that right now. It would have been interesting if someone "accidentally" brought ESS pods just to see how well they work.
Would you by chance be at the Solid Symposium?

> <@cxres-562ffb0816b6c7089cb87e14:gitter.im> Would you by chance be at the Solid Symposium?

I haven't considered it.

> <@mrkvon:matrix.org> I haven't considered it.

The reason I asked is, if you are interested, I could accommodate you for a lightening talk about your e-mail notifications at my session.
You don't need to be present in person, just make sure your camera and mic work!

> <@cxres-562ffb0816b6c7089cb87e14:gitter.im> The reason I asked is, if you are interested, I could accommodate you for a lightening talk about your e-mail notifications at my session.

Thanks for the invite! Could you share more details about the format and scope (technical, usability, etc.) you have in mind for the lightning talk?

You can also PM me.

yep

digital signatures and followup on search/indexing
https://meet.jit.si/solid-practitioners

On the point if you have a group pod with webid authenticated members and every change event is tracked, then if a malicious group owner made changes, all can see that this was done by that member - so the group would know even if the history of the chat read permissions were removed.

title: Localization Meeting Tools and RDF Data Discussion
summary: Attendees confirmed participation in the Localization meeting, leading to a discussion and sharing of various internationalization (i18n) tools (Weblate, Fluent, Vue-i18n) and technical examples of using Wikidata for RDF data negotiation.

messages.body:

> 
> 2024-04-01 - Joint mtg. with CG - Indexing/Searching

> 2024-05-13 - Tools & Libraries
> 2024-05-27 - Notifications
> 2024-06-10 - RDF for Organizations

I'm planning to join the l10n meeting today
Since many people use Weblate, I'm curious which workflow you are using https://docs.weblate.org/en/latest/workflows.html
**all** Practioners meeting on localization, please join in 45 minutes from now at https://meet.jit.si/solid-practitioners
https://projectfluent.org/
https://hosted.weblate.org/projects/sai/
https://ldo.js.org/api/ldo/setLanguagePreferences/
For Vue devs, this looks really good: https://vue-i18n.intlify.dev/
I'm using https://fluent-vue.demivan.me/
https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q7802
Here's Tim's article on wikidata https://solidos.solidcommunity.net/public/2021/BuildingSolidAppsUsingPublicData-V3.html

In the left side menu you can also find `Concept URI`, which links to the URI representing bread - which is the one to use when you want to represent bread in your RDF.

e.g. `<#me> foaf:topic_interest <http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7802> .`

You can then get data about the concept using content negotiation. E.g. 

`curl -L http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7802 -H "Accept:text/turtle"`

title: Seeking Inspiring Solid Development Resources
summary: Mariha requested high-level vision and narrow technical resources to encourage a return to software development, receiving several links tailored to her background in distributed systems.

messages.body: I wonder if you could maybe point me to some inspiring resources about Solid?
something that could make someone who didn't do any meaningful coding for I don't know how many years now want to get back into software development or computer science or systems engineering

@mariha:matrix.org not sure if that is too specialized, but maybe you can dig into https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/ressourcen-aus-dem-solidverse-matthias-evering?trk=public_profile_article_view (that is unfortunately not clickable) or in my private, unordered but extensive bookmarks https://www.serverproject.de/internal/bookmarks.htm

Thanks, that's a lot of resources! 

I don't speak German, but I have a solid computer science background (MSc from Jagiellonian University and ENS de Lyon) and I worked as a software engineer i.a. at IBM Cloud Object Storage (formerly Cleversafe). I have most experience in Java/JVM ecosystem and distributed systems, that I kind of specialised in. Never did web development or JavaScript, but had an exposure to a variety of different programming languages and decentralised software architectures. I liked algos and data structures most, and things related to programming languages themselves. I am dyslexic so I am kind of naturally attracted to any topics related to code readability, different programming paradigms, syntax expressiveness etc.

So I guess technically it's probably not too specialised, but I would most like to find some very high-level vision resources that will spark my heart and something very narrow that I can start with to focus on. Might be some small code contributions, but it is hard for me to motivate myself to work in JS, for too many reasons.

concerning the language, my writing english is better than my spoken english ;-) I have no extensive programming experience but am a strong fan of patterns of all kind. I stumbled about solid coincidentally, did some (very small) code contributions and maintain some pod providing services. we are always transparent and open, and - on this tuesday morning - I have two further resources for you that might help a) https://solid-contrib.github.io/getting-started/ b) https://github.com/0dataapp/hello/tree/main/solid/solid-file-client ... for Mariha ... heads up !

messages.body:
Hey Jeff Zucker and @room  
Who else is working on web component and solid and how can we group up ?
(A matrix channel , a form thread , a github repo ? )
Maybe we can see who's interested in working with web component and have a first visio all together see who is doing what and how we organize ourself

@aveltens:matrix.org , @madnificent:chat.semantic.works, @timbot1789:matrix.org, Theo is suggesting a web-components meetup.  I am all for it.  I know Wednesday at 16:00 UTC sometimes works for Angelo, will that work for Tim, Aad, and Theo?  Anyone else we should invite?

I think it would be nice , if they want to, to have Noel De Martin  and Jackson Morgan. I think it is important that if we build web component they integrate well with both LDO and aerogel, and see they things could overlap.
yes, hopefully everthing will play nicely with each other

I would be interested to participate in the discussion. When Polymer came out I made few prototypes, later used its successor LitElement once or twice. It has been a while but I recall that web components are relatively simple, just props down, events up and slots. Back in the days I was using them with Redux, I guess there would still be a need for some higher level connected components / containers which would use one of the solid clients.
mine are all based on rdflib and communica - a simple html can run SPARQL and other queries, display and update forms, pull RDF, etc.
would be great to have demos of all the different web component based projects that were mentioned during today's meeting
for sure, do you have a suggestion on best way to schedule the meeting?
i imagine that using mix of different components where each bundles a different solid clients, rdf parsers etc. could result in really bloated bundles
Mondays I hard for me but can manage sometimes, more up to you and others who actually develop those web components.
OTOH - since Angelo's components and mine are based on rdflib we can share across them
I think I'll create a web-components chat channel where we can coordinate

i'm curiuous how the dependencies are managed, i recall back in Polymer days they were trying to use yarn as default package manager to use it's flat dependency install, otherwise bundles would end up with multiple different versions of the same dependency
I think #solid_app-development:gitter.im could work, no that much traffic there
My rule of thumb is to only create new channel if an existing one gets too busy, over long period of time, with some specific topic.

> <@jeff-zucker:matrix.org> @aveltens:matrix.org , @madnificent:chat.semantic.works, @timbot1789:matrix.org, Theo is suggesting a web-components meetup.  I am all for it. My components are not in one bigÂ bundle but in smallÂ esmÂ modules that get loaded as needed. But you are right that something like rdflib would not be shared by default between two unrelated libs ,since both would bundle it independently. A solution could beÂ to have it as a peer dependencyÂ and expect the consumer to add via import map and e.g. esm.sh cdn
Same - I try to write so it works by CDN or local install and there is no build step.

title: Planning and Technical Discussion for Solid Web Components Group
summary: The group scheduled a meeting to discuss technical challenges like reactive rendering and interoperability across Web Components, overcoming initial scheduling conflicts and timezone errors, and subsequently launched a dedicated GitHub wiki for ongoing collaboration.

messages.body:

(btw, it seems like that's the same time the SolidOS meetings are happening, right? It's not a problem for me, but I'm saying it just in case)
This may be relevant for the web components efforts https://custom-elements-everywhere.com/

A question I've run into is interoperability in how reactive rendering works across web components. My preferred approach at the moment is to use a central state with web components subscribing to changes (currently implemented with rdflib.js by listening for added or new triples using a particular subject). Not immediately compatible with other components that refresh a vdom tree through properties/attributes.
Same, mine all share the store and authenticated fetcher and since I use neither frameworks nor shadow-dom, they should play well with others, excited to see how all our work can merge

title: Sleepy.bike Project Experiences Internal Schism
summary: Mariha updated the community on the difficult internal situation of the sleepy.bike project, confirming a 'schism' resulting in two incomplete, one-person teams.

messages.body:
> <@mariha:matrix.org> I am a bit confused with my recent interactions, and I might have confused people with indirect communication when joining the room. Usually I communicate very directly, and with the message above I didn't want to say that I have anything against Inrupt hackathons (just in case it was understood like this).
> sleepy.bike won one of them, but as I remember I didn't participate in the hackathon activities except making the explainer / demo, so it's hard to say that I have any experiences, good or bad... I was happy for our three-people team at the time that we won ðŸŽ‰.
> I am also confusing speaking for myself as an individual (first part of this and the above message) and speaking as a project representative (second part of this and the above message). We haven't figured it out internally in the project what is our structure or outside communication style, what came out recently in the context of the presentation, and we are doing it right now (mostly internally). 
> Thanks for your understanding.

An update from the sleepy.bike project: we still didn't find a way forward from the stalemate we had reached with the events accompanying our project's presentation at last Solid World. 

I don't know how to speak about what happened while respecting Michal's standards of privacy, but I wanted to voice out somehow the very difficult situation we have.

> <@mariha:matrix.org> An update from the sleepy.bike project: we still didn't find a way forward from the stalemate we had reached with the events accompanying our project's presentation at last Solid World. 
> 
> I don't know how to speak about what happened while respecting Michal's standards of privacy, but I wanted to voice out somehow the very difficult situation we have.

what stalemate do you mean? I watched your presentation at Solid World but I'm not sure I know what you're talking about.
Our project is experiencing a schizma.
mariha:   What does that mean?
It means that there are two one-person teams in sleepy.bike now.
None of them are complete, in the sense of controlling all the means of providing value for the community we wanted to serve.
@mariha:matrix.org - I'm sorry to hear there are ongoing troubles.  I'm not sure there's anything this group can do other than wish things work out for the best for each of you and for the project.
Just that you know that under normal* conditions I would be a different person. If we ever meet again I hope I'll figure out my life until that time. Good luck to you too.

title: Australian Startup Introduction and Collaboration Inquiry
summary: A non-technical startup from Australia introduced themselves, expressing interest in integrating Solid Pods and seeking connections with local experts or Inrupt for collaboration.

messages.body:
Hi Solid Community,

We're a passionate startup from Australia, and we've recently been inspired by the Solid project. Its principles resonate deeply with our vision of a more decentralised, user-controlled internet, and we're excited to integrate Solid into our offerings by providing pods for our clients.

As non-technical founders, we've been diving into the project, but we know there's a lot more to learn and many ways to collaborate. We're looking to connect with anyone who has experience with Solid, whether you're a freelancer, developer, or simply someone who can offer guidance.

Weâ€™d love to chat about how we can work together or if you could point us in the direction of someone in Australia or at Inrupt who might be interested in collaborating.

Looking forward to hearing from this amazing community!

Cheers,
Sai

Dear SOLID Community,

My name is Mohammad Bahrani, and Iâ€™m a research associate in the Web and Internet Science (WAIS) group at the University of Southampton. Iâ€™m currently working on a project focused on efficient, secure, and sovereign search over personal repositories across Solid pods. My main research contributions will be in the areas of information retrieval, large language models (LLMs), and federated learning within this context.

title: SolidCouch Conflict and Code of Conduct Committee Status
summary: A conflict arose regarding the SolidCouch repository ownership and license changes, leading to the conflict being referred to the CoC Committee, followed by a memberâ€™s departure and confirmation that CoC reporting is now handled by ODI Ombuds.

messages.body:
The SolidCouch repository is stolen* from OHN/sleepy.bike project.

* moved with no permission from the community, other co-admins or contributors (so the references are kept), renamed and forked back

It would be great if it was returned.
This change of license was illegal: https://github.com/solidcouch/solidcouch/blame/1ca1193366ff5b1f5feede182f24d64ea3a9f178/LICENSE

To clarify these concerns, I moved the [repository](https://github.com/solidcouch/solidcouch), which I authored almost entirely, into a new organization in August, and I [publicly announced it](https://mrkvon.org/blog/announcing-solidcouch). I respected the original MIT license [for all contributions that were not mine](https://github.com/solidcouch/solidcouch/pull/119). Despite suggesting mediation, there has been no resolution, and I will not engage further on this matter under current circumstances.

I regret that the conflict has come to this space. This will be my final statement on the matter here. If anybody has any concerns, please feel free to contact me directly. Thank you for your understanding.

@mariha:matrix.org and @mrkvon:matrix.org  - I am sorry to hear that your project is having difficulties.  As I've said before, I do not think that the Practitioners is the appropriate place to air your concerns.  I am not sure if your situation falls under the purview of the Solid Code of Conduct Committee, but if you feel it does, you should contact @VirginiaBalseiri:matrix.org . I hope the situation can be resolved to both of your satisfactions but I'm afraid that needs to happen outside of the Practitioners.
Thanks, I read the Solid Code of Conduct and I'll contact the Committee, as I should have done long ago, following the Solid World events that lead to the conflict.
(a private harassment)

Hi mariha: I would like to understand what prevents you from simply forking the codebase and continuing with your work. I don't understand the whole situation but often there is a way to focus energy on continuing development rather than loosing energy on arguments. Again this is a general observation and nothing specific to your situation.
Please ask any clarifying questions in OHN/conflict-resolution or if you prefer, privately to me.
I hope next time there will be a better climate for honest greetings and welcoming words, sorry for forgetting about the conventions. Hi!

Hey guys,

I have functional hyperandrogenism as a result of stress I was exposed to in recent years and I'll leave this space now with a hope to find some peace of mind / as means of self-protection.

Be aware that the Solid Code of Conduct committee does not answer requests due to transitioning under ODI so the presence of CoC gives a false sense of protection. I would consider removing it.

I hope you develop web 3.0 as an inclusive and safe space for everyone to participate. Good luck with that!

I enjoyed meeting with you in this group. I truly believed I would go back to Software Engineering when the time is right. My father died and I didn't expect to be used as cannon fodder, but I learnt how important it is to choose the right people for myself to partner with.

Best,
mariha

I am deeply sorry to hear that this has happened.

I have [just made a post to the forums](https://forum.solidproject.org/t/code-of-conduct-committee/8150/2) announcing that ODI is now able to take on Ombuds activities - you can now send any CoC reports you have to solid-ombuds@theodi.org

I hope that we can all make the Solid Community a positive environment to build an inclusive, safe and ethical Web.

Mariha, I appreciated your participation in Practitioners and am sorry to see you go.  Unfortunately you caught the Code of Conduct Committee in exactly the the weeks of transition from Solid Team to ODI.  Best of luck in your next endeavors.
As a likely object of Mariha's complaint, I'll be happy to engage in a resolution process in an appropriate space and form. Feel free to contact me on Matrix if you have any questions!
Travelling right now, will be more available in about a week.

title: Restructuring the Solid Catalog Repository
summary: The team decided to separate the Solid Catalog data from specific applications by moving it to its own repository to improve data independence and requested community feedback on the structure.

messages.body: Jeff Zucker: I recall our chat about separating catalog data from any particular app, seeing this issue i think it would be great to do it asap https://github.com/solid-contrib/catalog/issues/5

> <@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im> Jeff Zucker: I recall our chat about separating catalog data from any particular app, seeing this issue i think it would be great to do it asap https://github.com/solid-contrib/catalog/issues/5

Yes, I'll move it to its own repo today, have been meaning to, just too much going on.

I have created a [repo for the catalog separate from the apps which will access it](https://github.com/solid/catalog/).  I've also posted some proposals on how to structure the catalog there as issues.  Your feedback is most welcome!

title: ActivityPods Presentation and Technical Discussion
summary: Following a presentation on ActivityPods, the group engaged in a technical discussion covering group pods, ActivityPub implementation over Solid, ODRL, and RDF document structure requirements related to triple/quad stores.

messages.body: #solid-practitioners:matrix.org - good news, Sebastien from the ActivityPod project will present at our December 5 meeting.

Interested in  the ActivityPods ideas aroud pods for groups -- the way it works in SolidOS, an Organization is an agent, a social entity, and has veruous related vcard groups of people (or other orgs).
Eg https://solidproject.solidcommunity.net/Solid%20Project%20Contacts/index.ttl#this is an addressBook which ha the groups around the soolid project
Maybe pick up tech discussion of runnig AP on top of Solid ... I am curious what sort of a container AP has which Solid does not have
ODRL
W3C spec: https://www.w3.org/TR/odrl-model/ ; Community Group continuing the work: https://www.w3.org/community/odrl/
https://activitypods.org/specs/activitypub
Pierre-Antoine: Is your experiment with AP layer on top of Solid published somewhere?

Would be a great discussion to have. I initially thought that is what CODs would provide an avenue for until further explained by elf-pavlik (elf Pavlik) . I do believe thereâ€™s long-term interests in group support especially as there are ActivityPub platforms that operate on a â€œgroupâ€ model such as Reddit alternatives Kbin and Lemmy as well as forums which support ActivityPub such as Discourse and NodeBB
Today's [minutes](https://github.com/solid-contrib/practitioners/blob/main/meetings/2024-12-05.md) are online, feel free to add or edit by PR.  GREAT meeting, thanks all.
Could whomever recording the meeting give me a link to the recording

sro81:  I wanted to ask you about the AP need for a single subject in an RDF file - is the subject assumed to be \<>, the document itself that points to a the main topic subject or is it the main topic itself?
And if the single subject has predicates pointing to other subjects, must those be in a separate document or could they be in the same document?
We do not dissociate the subject and the document. So it is the main topic itself.

No they must be in a separate document. The reason why we cannot do that at the moment is that we use a triple store, not a quad store. When we will move to a quad store in version 3, all documents will be in their own named graph. So to get the content of a document, we will only need to fetch the content of the named graph.
Not sure what you mean there.  Is the URL of the subject the document or a document fragment?
Will version 3 solve the issue you brought up with typeIndexes?
Yes ! But I still think we should always have predicates to link ressources, so that we really have "linked data" :)
I agree but on the level of best practice rather than a MUST though any given app could insist I guess
The document ?
So if the subject is foo.ttl, it is assumed that any subject it contains is the one we want without having to specify that subject?
Yes. Except we don't deal with files, so no .ttl extension.

I think one of the things Solid is missing is a validation of inboxes. E.g. if I allow some subset of agents to append to a resource/container, they're able to add whatever [valid turtle] they want, and I won't even know who appended what, except if they sign it.

title: Node Solid Server (NSS) Deployment Troubleshooting
summary: A developer struggled with deploying NSS using Nginx and SSL until they identified and resolved a configuration mismatch in their firewall rules, confirming the use of Solid for multi-tenancy in a production app.

messages.body:
Hello All. (New to Solid)

I wanted to reach out and ask for advice to overcome a hurdle that is leaving me scratching my head. I am currently making attempts to deploy the NSS and seems like it does and does not work at the same time. I attempted to follow the documentation on Github and set up a reverse proxy using Nginx and link the server through the proxy_pass. The first issue I ran into was my SSL certificate did not like that the Solid server  domain name "localhost". I have since corrected that issue and now a face new problem. When I attempt to go to the domain that is attributed to the server my request times out, but if I curl the URL I get the index.html page. When I attempt to curl anywhere else besides the "/" for the domain I am hit with a 401 on the server side. I since figured out how to register a profile thinking that would let me at least gain access. However, even though I set up an account, I still am unable to access the server from a browser. Not sure what do here.  All advice is welcomed. 

Thank you.

Hi v3x4s I would first note that self-hosting is not a requirement to use Solid. If you want to sign up for a Pod on a server that is already deployed then you can use https://solidcommunity.net or any other already hosted instance listed in https://solidproject.org/for-developers.

If you do want to self-host, I would recommend going for the newer CommunitySolidServer (https://communitysolidserver.github.io/CommunitySolidServer/latest/) rather than the NodeSolidServer

Can I ask what are you looking to do with Solid - build apps, use apps, test things out? The answer might help guide the best approach for you.

Hello. I have utilized the community Solid Server as well as deployed it locally on my host PC. This time around is a bit different given that I building an official app that will go into production. I realize as I am typing this my name is not displaying, but I have met some people in this chat before. I am Brandon the developer for DataSolids, the health app company that joins the Wednesday meetings. I am utilizing the solid server for multi tenancy and making the pod part of the backend for user data storage.

Hi just wanted to follow up on my previous comment. I was able to resolve the issue an get the server up and running. What I initially thought was a cert mismatch or config issue was a really mismatch rule in the firewall.

title: Solid Integration with Model Context Protocol (MCP) and LLM Privacy
summary: Participants discussed the feasibility of creating a Solid adapter for Anthropic's Model Context Protocol (MCP), debating how MCP and RAG approaches differ concerning data querying, local data manipulation, and the privacy risks associated with LLM training on user data.

messages.body:
Claude now seems to have a model context protocol for helping it get access to different data stores to contextualise conversations. Has anyone tried implementing a Solid adapter for it?
 - https://www.anthropic.com/news/model-context-protocol
 - https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol
i'll be interested in the topic. We also asked ourselves how this could be done at Virtual Assembly. I am not sure it would be so easy...

an example of "graph" data used in MCP :
https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/servers/tree/main/src/memory
Not sure if it's just my matrix client but I don't see any of your text with the original reply, just a quote of what is said

i wrote earlier: "i'll be interested in the topic. We also asked ourselves how this could be done at Virtual Assembly. I am not sure it would be so easy...
"
Any insights into the difficulties (I've not really looked at the protocol )
the main problem for me is that i am stil figuring out the use cases :)
and how this works entirely
I previously studied a bit the RAG approach. it seems like it is different from MCP: https://ryanoattes.scribe.rip/graph-driven-rag-approaches-compared-6470e36d99d9

Maybe a good read is the HN thread on the topic, to start with:
https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=42237424
I can see there that JSON can be used as input, so I guess JSON-LD would also work...

it looks to me that the goal with MCP is to let the LLM (claude in this case) have access to some dataset. You can then use the prompts to manipulate this data. see examples here: https://glama.ai/blog/2024-11-25-model-context-protocol-quickstart
Does Claude use our data to train itself?

My first intuition was totally different. I thought that the LLM would take the data (some RDF in our case) and process it into its Model in order to give more accurate answers based on contextualised data. But, as far as i understood so far, this i snot the case at all. Please anybody, tell me that i am wrong.
Claude is an LLM, created by Anthropic

> <@nikob:matrix.org> Claude is an LLM, created by Anthropic

Yes, I use it via Duck Duck Go which means it does not use its sessions with me to train itself ... Ideally we  can eventually have a pod-based llm that does learn from our sessions but only the local llm does the learning.

I am not sure if MCP is about the LLM learning anything. I know that their marketing is confusing. by example: they say MCP can provide "additional context to LLM-powered applications like Claude.ai. Think of it as a standardized way to feed external information into AI models".

But then the only examples I see are different. they are about using the prompt of Claude to query a dataset. Like you say you can query duckduckgo with Claude. Will Claude "learn" anything from your interactions with the dataset? I don't know. this is an open question for me at the moment
With DuckDuckGo, the answer is no ^^
Note the message on the right saying that my session is not used to train the LLMs
I guess the men in Black wave their little wand after our conversations and Claude forgets.
Presumably DuckDuckGo or someone else can do the same for MCPs ... but ideally we could have our own models learn without training the company's model.

(I forgot that Jeff cannot use threads properly on his device. sorry about that).
Claude or any LLM can indeed improve their model when you use their centralized service/APIs and you gave consent (I guess). In the case of DuckDuckGo, the consent is no. That's one thing.
Now talking about MCP, seems to be another thing altogether.
It doesn't seem to me that Claude will learn anything from your interactions with datasets defined by MCP.
MCP is more like a connector to let you manipulate the dataset with Claude. It happens locally only, and the LLM in itself will not be modified by your local interactions with your MCP data sets. Correct me if I am wrong
I guess we can only train a model with our local data if we run the LLM locally too, which is not the case for Claude (as it isn't open source anyway).
The LLM has to see the data to process it.  Without guarantee it forgets my data, consent is meaningless.
And I don't see why data passed in via an MCP would be any different.

I see!
So only if you run the LLM locally (which needs huge amount of resources, and needs also an open source LLM), then you never have control over privacy guarantees
And MCP will always send the data to the central servers of Anthropic?
That's how I understand it.  But hopefully there can be a combined remote and local LLM that uses computing power from the remote and data from local

> <@nikob:matrix.org> And MCP will always send the data to the central servers of Anthropic?

I don't know, perhaps it's possible to run your own MCP and your own version of Claude.
maybe this is what MCP is all about. and in this case, your local data would not enrich the LLM... I guess
your own version of Claude, I bet not. as it is not open source
right, your own version of an open source llm
except a hybrid version that uses a central dataset plus your own or ability to connect to federated datasets

I think what MCP does eventually (but it is just a guess) is that it uses some abstract reasoning features that are already in the LLM, because Anthropic "taught" Claude how to use its MCP API. And then you can connect any kind of data that respects the MCP APIs/specs locally, and Claude will be able to manipulate and do some reasoning on it, without the need to send the local data to its central servers nor to integrate the data into the global model.
Someone might make an LLM specialized for ornithology ... my local LLM would use that plus my own data about what birds are in my yard
If I like the ornithology LLM, I can donate my data to it but only if I want to

Ok. i think MCP for now is based on generic features of Claude that knows how to manipulate "any dataset". I dont think the local data is used to generate new embeddings. or maybe only "local embeddings" if this can even be....
I agree it's quite possible to make a flow where the central model doesn't store our data, but I also believe most central models will want to store it
I am clearly not even a the beginner level for LLM, so I will let anybody else who knows better enlighten us.
Good plan, I await enlightenment.
But i got your point Jeff! thanks
Thanks for the MCP links, I will go read up on them.

> <@nikob:matrix.org> I see!
> So only if you run the LLM locally (which needs huge amount of resources, and needs also an open source LLM), then you never have control over privacy guarantees

Not necessarily for a huge amount of resource to run it locally. It ultimately depends on the model and what tasks as use cases you have for it. Itâ€™s trivial to run an SLM and smaller LLMs locally

I asked Claude, and this is what he said "I am an AI model with defined capabilities that were established during my initial training by Anthropic. I do not have independent access to store, train on, or learn from any data shared with me in our conversations."

for those that are open source yes. so not in the case of CLaude and its MCP feature. But I get your point. Your example is about building an LLM from your own data. That's fine, it is is a different topic I guess
so in a way, i was correct ;) they trained Claude to use the MCP APIs, and Claude can do some manipulation on the local data, if the schema is provided.
It is a smart move to ask CLaude about MCP :)

> <@nikob:matrix.org> so in a way, i was correct ;) they trained Claude to use the MCP APIs, and Claude can do some manipulation on the local data, if the schema is provided. 

If Claude wasn't lying, yes :-)
If their constitutional focus is to be believed lol
Claude and I are friends, so he might be lying to you indeed
I am more interested in RAG... what I posted in the thread. because it is supposed to integrate the dataset into the model...
(a local model I guess)
but MCP is also cool. it is like: "look Claude I have this dataset, can you help me make sense of it and do some queries and stuff on it? and he will say yes"
and you can express your queries as prompts (plain english) so it is cool

but AFAIU, it doesn't alter the model. It is just claude that has built-in generic capabilities to query datasets now, and plugs into any local MCP datasets. so it can translate plain english queries into actual data queries on your dataset
and then kinds of read the query results to and translates that into plain english too

I've done that on a small manual scale.  For example, I pasted the SHACL Compact Spec in and then asked told it what I wanted the shape like and it came up with a pretty good one.  Or I pasted in a list of world countries by GDP and list of countries by percentage of Android users and had the LLM compare them
i see it as a dataset assistant

nice! and now with MCP, the difference is that you do not need to copy paste the data into the prompt, but instead can refer to the dataset with an ID/connector that has been configured locally in Claude Desktop
so claude can directly plug itself to it
yes MCP sounds great for this kind of thing

Yeah, that shows really good benefits. I was pairing using specific GPTs from ChatGPT and then using that data with Claude to get a pretty high quality output. This appears to be a more streamlined version of that
I think Jeff and Damon, we did a pretty good job at understanding MCP this evening ;) time for me to go sleep a bit
thanks for the company and understandings
Thanks to you both as well.
Btw whenever you guys get a chance gou should look into Mamba models which use Selective State Space (SSSMs) architecture as opposed to the standard more common Transformer architecture
I wonâ€™t infodump but if you guys have heard of Perplexity, it works well and thereâ€™s an Open Source alternative that works pretty good https://www.morphic.sh/
https://mplx.run/ this as well
Just asked Morphic the diff btwn RAG and MCP and it gave an informative answer.
You used to be able to change the models before they introduced a pro subscription

title: LLM Data Transparency, Consent, and Linked Data
summary: The discussion revolves around the lack of guaranteed data forgetting in LLMs, incentives for forgetting data during training, and sharing resources related to AI data transparency and the connection between LLM and linked data.

messages.body:
> <@jeff-zucker:matrix.org> The LLM has to see the data to process it.  Without guarantee it forgets my data, consent is meaningless.

No guarantee, but running a neural network today (and thus LLM) for training is more expensive than for predicting for each run. This due to the calculation of gradient descent for training (the data would likely be fed in multiple times too but that's not an absolute requirement for your data to be used). No guarantee, but at least there is an incentive.
This seems relevant to the conversation : https://theodi.org/insights/reports/the-ai-data-transparency-index/
^^Claude got very low scores for a) copyright material in dataset b) personal information in dataset.

on the topic of linked data and LLM

https://sigmoid.social/@lysander07/113327453670382156

Is it like IPFS that a group of people or organizations run nodes?

> <@jeff-zucker:matrix.org> I've added links from the Practioners peertube to videos by Angelo and Noel.  If anyone else has video sites, let me know.  @jeswr-5f532665d73408ce4fee1daf:gitter.im - there is an easy import-from-Vimeo button that could snarf up all the Solid World videos and put them on peertube. It even imports the text description and other metadata.  Maybe talk to @DeadSuperHero:matrix.org to see how much space you can use.

Ah brilliant ðŸ‘ , Sean Tilley:  it would be good to know how much we can use. At a guess we'd have about 50GB work of video; (50 1hr videos that were approx 1gb at time of upload).

I've also got a few questions:
Does peertube automatically apply any compression?
What is the data redundancy of of spectra.video like - if this is self hosted with your own storage rather than being an ipfs model; do you have reliable backups?
Related to who pays for it, is it sustainable - what is the likelihood of the service being shut down / disappearing?

> <@timbl-54d26c98db8155e6700f7312:gitter.im> Who pays for peertube storage?

In the case of PeerTube, the admin is responsible for their own server. However, other servers can also assist in redundancy by hosting copies of media, and act as peers for the video player to improve bandwidth.

I pay for storage costs on my server, but the server is also funded through OpenCollective. Object Storage for media is relatively inexpensive, so I can host a considerable amount of media files for a sustainable cost.

> <@jeswr-5f532665d73408ce4fee1daf:gitter.im> Ah brilliant ðŸ‘ , Sean Tilley:  it would be good to know how much we can use. At a guess we'd have about 50GB work of video; (50 1hr videos that were approx 1gb at time of upload).
> I've also got a few questions:
> Does peertube automatically apply any compression?
> What is the data redundancy of of spectra.video like - if this is self hosted with your own storage rather than being an ipfs model; do you have reliable backups?
> Related to who pays for it, is it sustainable - what is the likelihood of the service being shut down / disappearing?

All good questions! There is no cap on uploads, due to Object Storage being quite affordable. 

1. All videos are transcoded into HLS, which optimizes for streaming on PeerTube's video player. 

2. I use an Object Storage layer separate from a self-hosted server. Linode has regular scheduled backups, last I checked they are daily. 

3. I have run the instance for almost two years now? Spectra utilizes an OpenCollective that has greatly helped in keeping the operation affordable as membership scales up.
In case anyone is curious, the OpenCollective can be found here: https://opencollective.com/spectra-video

I would maybe be interested in hosting an instance on timbl.com with copies of the any solid stuff for redundancy. But without providing bandwidth commitment so use not for streaming by users only syncing by admins does that make sense ?
I would get a USB drive dedicated for that presumably
If the solid world stuff is 50GB is that in original form?  When Peer Tube compresses for streaming does it do that at multiple levels?

> <@timbl-54d26c98db8155e6700f7312:gitter.im> If the solid world stuff is 50GB is that in original form?  When Peer Tube compresses for streaming does it do that at multiple levels?

Hard for me to quantify, I would say that extant factors include multiple resolutions of videos. Broadly speaking, we encode whatever the original format is, plus a lower 360p resolution. So, let's say that you upload 50GB worth of video, you'd have that plus the smaller resolution version that gets generated. Let's estimate that to about 75GB, give or take.

I will state that Object Storage has largely made the cost of hosting the media files themselves somewhat negligible. I'm close to a terrabyte of media for my instance; Object Storage ensures that storage is utilized separately from my server application and hosting infrastructure.

The way that PeerTube works is simple: videos are not themselves federated across servers (except in cases of redundancy), but the metadata that effectively acts like a catalogue entry is what gets federated.
The PeerTube player utilizes some Peer to Peer functionality on the player end between viewers, but that's just chunks of video data to assist with loading.
I suppose the total storage depends on (a) what was the encoding of the original vs HLS output + how many resolutions are chosen to generate: https://docs.joinpeertube.org/admin/configuration
