title: SoSy 2025 Sessions: Solid Together and ESPRESSO Decentralized Search
summary: Announcements were made for two sessions at the Solid Symposium 2025: 'Solid Together,' seeking projects for societal good, and the ESPRESSO workshop, focused on developing solutions for decentralized search across Solid pods while respecting access rights.

messages.body:
Jeff Zucker, niko at NextGraph.org and I are pleased to announce the [Solid Together](https://cxres.inrupt.net/public/SoSy25/solid-together/) session at the third [Solid Symposium](https://sosy2025.eu) in Leiden, Netherlands on 24-25 April 2025.

The [Solid Together](https://cxres.inrupt.net/public/SoSy25/solid-together/) session, organized by Solid Practitioners, aims to highlight the various projects around the world that use Solid to serve the greater good in society.

If you are participating in such a project, we invite you to speak at our session. If you know of someone working on such a project, please spread the word. You may submit your contributions by sending an e-mail to the organizers listed on the session [webpage](https://cxres.inrupt.net/public/SoSy25/solid-together/).

[The ESPRESSO team](https://espressoproject.org/)  invites you to join our workshop on **Information Retrieval in Decentralized and/or Federated Systems** at [SoSy 2025](https://www.sosy2025.eu/).

This is an opportunity for practitioners from across the globe to meet face-to-face and learn how each
other's work is contributing to the challenges that matter in our communities.

Increasingly, the international community of Solid practitioners is looking at how we can query pods, and how we can query and search pods while taking into account Solidâ€™s varying and dynamic access
permissions.

We expect that our workshop will be of particular interest to the wider Solid community, as
well as to the wider IR community, including those working with more traditional centralized
architectures.

This will be a hands-on session: if you have a project ready to demonstrate, demo it; if you have code
you're still working on, talk us through it; if you have a high-level design, walk us through it. Tell us about
the people your project is helping, has helped, or will help; and how.

The ESPRESSO team is developing a novel experimental framework to solve the critical problem in Solid's decentralized private web environment, which is this: **how do you search between Solid pods, when access to the resources in those pods depends on widely varying access rights?**

The advent of effective search engines was an inflection point in the publicâ€™s adoption of the World Wide Web. More recently, the disadvantages of the centralized paradigm in Web search are becoming more and more apparent, as previously popular search engines return poorer-quality or even erroneous results, and providers of alternative search engines aiming to provide better-quality results face difficulties in scaling
their offerings to return results of sufficient quality and relevance.

Privacy of search has been a priority
for alternative search engine providers for some years; and more recently, creators have been calling for more respect for their intellectual property rights in order to protect their work from being incorporated into AI (artificial intelligence) training data.

**ESPRESSO** is the first project to take on access rights as a first-class component of decentralized
search. We will open the session by demonstrating ESPRESSO's approach to a realistic scenario of
medical research over patient records in Solid pods.

During the session, IR practitioners will present their innovative solutions, and by the end, IR
practitioners working in Solid, FAIR, Linked Data, and adjacent fields will know how their work relates to
others.

**Organizers:** 

Helen Oliver, Birkbeck, University of London, [h.oliver@bbk.ac.uk](mailto:h.oliver@bbk.ac.uk); 

Mohammad Bahrani,
University of Southampton, [m.bahrani@soton.ac.uk](mailto:m.bahrani@soton.ac.uk)
In addition, if any of you are interested in speaking at the ESPRESSO workshop, do please email me at [h.oliver@bbk.ac.uk](mailto:h.oliver@bbk.ac.uk) by 16 January!
"how do you search between Solid pods, when access to the resources in those pods depends on widely varying access rights?" ... is there a link to this framework?
Found it ... https://www.researchgate.net/publication/381464447_Decentralized_Search_over_Personal_Online_Datastores_Architecture_and_Performance_Evaluation
We think the answer to this is a standardized solid spec for a /search api on the server

title: Authentication for Non-Web Applications
summary: A user asked for guidance on authenticating a local Python program to read files from a Solid Pod, leading to a discussion on the lack of standardization for non-browser authentication and the availability of CSS client credentials as a server-specific alternative.

messages.body:
Is there a library that provides authN for a non-website application, to READ a file it has access to? 

Hi, sorry I am new to practising Solid. I am trying to create a local Python program to connect to my Pod (https://solidcommunity.net/), and READ a file. On the Pod provider website I gave access to localhost:1234, and in my local program I am adding localhost:1234 as the origin in the header. I tried other headers like a Bearer with my webID token. 
I understand authN is difficult, so is there any guidance for how I can get a successful READ from a local program to a pod to work, without requiring the pod owner user in the request? Seen https://docs.inrupt.com/developer-tools/javascript/client-libraries/tutorial/authenticate-nodejs-web-server/# and https://github.com/jeff-zucker/solid-shell  and https://ldo.js.org/guides/solid\_react/#4-implementing-loginlogout-in-the-header
https://github.com/jeff-zucker/solid-file-client
Authentication outside of browsers is not standardised so this will not work with all servers
Oh ok I see, thank you! I see this issue for the specs is for server side apps auth: https://github.com/solid/specification/issues/504

Hi Areeba,
To follow what jesse said, Solid auth is based on OIDC which is ment for the web and ask for user interaction in order to sign in.  However, if your pod in hoster on a CSS instance, you can use the client credentials API, but this will make your script only work with CSS pod
https://communitysolidserver.github.io/CommunitySolidServer/latest/usage/client-credentials/
Oh ok! Thank you!!

No, you have things mixed.  Solid-File-Client does not handle auth and works with any server given the right auth client. One needs to bring an auth-client to it.   Solid-File-Client can be used in a browser and outside a browser with Inrupt's or any other auth client.  It's ability to be used on a server is entirely dependent on what auth library you bring to it. Outside a browser, it can be used with my Solid-Node-Client which is a switcher for auth-clients that supports using either solid-auth-fetcher or Inrupt's solid-auth client.  It used to work with all servers, but changes in how ESS and CSS handle external clients means that it currently only works with NSS.

title: Discussion on AI Code Generation Effectiveness
summary: Members shared mixed feedback on the utility and security of GenAI code editors/copilots, discussing both positive formatting capabilities and negative experiences involving bugs and potential security vulnerabilities.

messages.body:
Also wanted to make a slightly off-topic remark to say that I'm increasingly impressed with code-editors using GenAI (https://blog.jeswr.org/2025/03/18/impressed-by-cursor).

I wrote this blog off the back of the LWS WG call on Monday where there was a discussion about getting the syntax right for some of the spec documents - and it turns out that copilots have become quite good at those kind of formatting tasks.

I quantify my success with co-pilots at 25% ... from introducing functions from other languages, to ad-infinitum "yes i see the mistake, let me generate again with the same mistake" they can help with some tasks but can be a burden at others. A couple of weeks ago I spent 7 days debugging some CYPHER query that the copilots generated - and it worked well on the CLI as parts (that's how it was built) but consistently failed when joined together. After reading most of the documentation (which then negates all the effort of using a copilot), the issue was that there was a type discrepancy between two subqueries ... which the co-pilots still "can't see". 

Regarding larger code generation, I am skeptical about security. In a post a few months ago I raised the "A & B & C" type attack, where the code generated is innocuous if you have 1 or 2 out of the 3 parts, but when combined it is a security breach. Since these could be large compound function calls, the surface area for testing is enormous.

title: Announcement of CSS Component Scaffolder Tool
summary: A developer announced and shared a new CSS component scaffolder tool designed to simplify the creation of new CSS components, such as API endpoints and login methods, aiming to reduce the learning curve.

messages.body:
Hello all,

Recently, I've been working extensively on building new CSS components. Starting from scratch each time was quite frustrating, so I've developed a [CSS component scaffolder](https://github.com/Liquid-Surf/css-component-generator). This tool generates new components based on templates, currently including:

- Adding a new API endpoint to CSS (from my work on [FedCM](https://github.com/Liquid-Surf/fedcm-demo)).
- Adding new login methods to CSS (from my work on [direct SSO auth](https://github.com/Liquid-Surf/css-direct-sso-auth)).
- A basic "hello world" component that logs to the console (based on the default [hello world](https://github.com/CommunitySolidServer/hello-world-component) example).

Going forward, each time I create a new component, I'll abstract its essential parts and incorporate it as a template. I'm also considering doing this with existing components.

The CSS learning curve can be steep, so I hope this scaffolder will help newcomers get started more easily. Feel free to suggest new template ideas or point me towards components you'd like to see converted into templates!
Great!

title: Defining the 'landingPage' Predicate in Catalog V2

I should put in a field description - it is for a page that describes the resource and has links to other information about it; it could be a homepage, a repo, a wiki, etc.

landingPage is a predicate in the DCAT ontology.
but yes, deciding on the actual predicates is a v3 issue (an imortant one)

title: Discussion on External Health Data Aggregation Plans

title: Datasolids Architecture, Security, and Solid Protocol Adherence
summary: A detailed debate occurred regarding Datasolids' use of an abstraction layer and a siloed system for health data to meet HIPAA security requirements, contrasting this approach with standard Solid interoperability principles.

messages.body: mwhaddle: Marc - I watched the datasolids video, and it looks to me the way you are doing it, you are effectively not using Solid at all.  That is, you are using some Solid pod server of some kind behind the internet, but the entire Solid API is not available to any user of the system?  In other words, you could use any backend you want in the installation you demoed and it would function the same and the data of all users is effectively siloed in your app?

Fred- Our focus is on a use case leveraging Solid principles to enable custody- and therefore control- of patient data in Healthcare/PLS. When we were fleshing out this use case, it became clear that the basic Solid pod model could not provide the security requirements for storing health data. Additionally, we at Datasolids are all risk & security practitioners so we take a brutally practical view in how we build things. Solid is the only framework we know of that enables the utility we are aiming for when it comes to patient control of their data, so we made some changes to the architecture to achieve the security profile needed for the use case. Could any backend work for the installation we demoed? Not for health data, or any other flavor of data deemed sensitive, we've found. User control of data is what we're focused on, and the highest measure of control comes from possession, or custody. We want to provide the most secure option available to achieve that, but also to protect what users hold in their pod. We tend to shy away from religious discussions about being failthful to a certain vision of the spec...we're more interested in real world traction. Given the growing awareness that users have basically no control of their data, and can't trust the incumbent stewards to effectively secure it....users want options, especially patients. We will give them those...
mwhaddle:  "the basic Solid pod model could not provide the security requirements for storing health data"  why do you think that?

When we started, we did a series of vulnerability assessments on the basic Solid Pod model & had concerns about the results. Given that there is a regulatory framework (HIPAA, PHI) in place for parties that store & exchange patient data, we would have to meet the same requirements as any other health data steward, as our intent is to give the patient technical parity with providers & payors in the ecosystem. This involves a big step-up in governance too, as much of the current principles are written under the guise of the individual not having storage/share capability, especially in healthcare.
One big requirement we identified for this use case was the need for an abstraction layer between the backend & frontend in order to handle the traffic flow & control the security around the Pod.
@mwhaddle:matrix.org were your vulnerability assessments of the Solid Pod model or of CSS?

What vulnerabilities, and when you say "basic Solid Pod" do you mean the open source pod providers?  I'm confident we have military level security beyond what is needed for health with TrinPod's approach, for example.
Other servers will have a different vulnerability profile.

Indeed. One big detail here- we are advancing a use case where Solid principles can make a real impact. Yes, the assessments were done on the basic open source model. At first, we built with NSS in mind, but switched to CSS as NSS isn't maintained as often as CSS. We haven't done a vulnerability assessment of CSS yet.
CSS is in no way an enterprise Solid Server, such as Inrupt or Trinpod, so for sure not the right candidate for your use case.

That's on the roadmap, as this likely will scale to a level where CSS isn't the better choice. At this stage, we are developing the pod user interface & the process/data flows, etc. There will be a need for a true ESS, of course when we reach production.

I would recommend either going for an enterprise server solution, or instead of building a fully incompatible abstraction layer, build another enterprise server solution that uses Solid.  Otherwise, I think you just have a fully siloed system and your users have no way to get their data out or share or read except through your proprietary API - which is no different than any other siloed application out there now?
If you do plan to go with an Enterprise solution eventually, I would ditch the abstraction layer in your prototype as that bypasses all things Solid.
I'm a very big fan of your use case, and think its the perfect candidate for Solid and solving the HIPAA issues by patients and providers controlling their own pods.
I would also go a step further on the xml data you have and translate in the pod to queryable linked data and capture the space-time of it so you can always look at current state vs past

Given the use case, a siloed system is a requirement. An abstraction layer puts a buffer between the patient's pod & the internet. That's a critical detail in the security profile. Our solution also contemplates the storage & sharing of data individually, but also collectively. So, for what we're building here, we're not using Solid to "do" something......we're doing something "using" Solid.
mwhaddle:   That makes no sense, you are just using a different security model to do the same thing as Solid Protocol which is fully secure with enterprise level servers
One additional (& huge) detail is that we must maintain the chain of custody of the health data. This is all about the performance of the security, not the mere presence of it.

You can capture full space-time events and complete history in the pods.  For example, in TrinPod, nothing is ever deleted - space-time is added to.  All events capture input and output state as well as the agent performing the function to make any change (including just read).  So full transparency down to the single triple/state level

"I would also go a step further on the xml data you have and translate in the pod to queryable linked data and capture the space-time of it so you can always look at current state vs past".... indeed. That makes the chain of custody easier to maintain....also provides a much better method to track/audit for HIPAA. One overarching intent is to have the best, most complete & current data under patient control. Provenance is no small part of that.
It is true that it took us many years of development to reach internet/enterprise scale with this approach.

Sure it does, when you contemplate what objects are being stored in the pod. If it's pictures & social media, that's one thing. This is health data, so a different beast. Siloed is necessary here, & not going to be a blocker for patient adoption. The big sea change is the custody of the data by the patient...they actually want a siloed system for this, with them holding the keys.

And the providers & payors actually like this approach, as it cleans up myriad process flows on their ends. It's when the notion emerges that the power imbalance has been negated & they no longer have exclusive control of patient data things get interesting....

title: Enterprise Solid Security, Interoperability, and HIPAA Compliance
summary: The discussion centered on whether Enterprise Solid is HIPAA compliant and how its security model (interoperable, non-siloed) compares to traditional siloed applications, noting that compliance largely depends on process.

messages.body: mwhaddle: I think my point here is regardless of what you store in the pod, with enterprise servers, its military level secure.  So creating yet another siloed application, which I think is what your abstraction layer would be doing, means that you would be very similar to other siloed approaches without adding in any way to the security you get (maybe diminishing actually) from the Enterprise Solid approach.  An analogy would be pre the web - when there were many "BBS" system (I hosted one on a commodore 64) each of those was separate vs. the web where things are interoperable.  You would effectively have a non-interoperable thing that you would have to sell.  With enterprise Solid, not only do you have security beyond the needs of healthcare, but the future-proof insurance that your users can switch to other providers when needed - no proprietary lock-in.
Is Enterprise Solid HIPAA compliant?

sorry to intervene - HIPAA / PCI / GDPR are mostly process-focused ... ACL is the only specific tech area (data protection = depends on how you encrypt and transfer / audit trails = shouldn't be stored in the same location / backup&recovery = process)
I'm aware. Would be interested to know of ESS has been subjected to HIPAA evaluation. My intital take is not.
If the issue is process while running the server, both ESS and TrinPod can be self-hosted.

title: MANDAT Project Requirements, Delegation, and Architecture
summary: Participants discussed the MANDAT project, focusing on its advanced Solid capabilities like organizational delegation and data provision chains, and sought clarification on the underlying legal and high-level requirements for bank/SMB use cases versus technical implementation details.

messages.body: At tomorrow's Practitioner's meeting we will hear from Christoph Braun about the MANDAT project which uses Solid to address issues of sensitive business data and about his new authentication library for Solid.  We will also hear from William Payne about his PodQuest search widget for pods.  See you there!

For those who missed it Christoph and team presented during the last Solid World https://spectra.video/w/7i3mmZHQu6PrkqsyHfTi1U?start=48m25s
I hope tomorrow we will be able to dive into more details ðŸ”ï¸
Cool, thanks! I hadn't seen it yet
I like the discussion of delegation at 1:03:00

The addition of organisational internal rights delegation, data grants, purpose-specific access granting, and data provision chains really takes Solid to another level! ðŸ¤©
I wish we could do all those things with all Solid servers.

Well, technically, all the proxies' (RDP for internal rights delegation, and DPP for data provisioning chains) APIs are basically Solid APIs. They expect Solid-OIDC and manage access to their API using WAC + policies for the specific proxy logic. So, I'd argue that these are Solid Protocol compliant :) From the outside, they look like any Solid Pod, except that they do not just serve data but do some additional logic as well.
uvdsl (Christoph Braun): Do you have a basic requirements document (no solutions, just the requirements) for the MANDAT effort?
I think there may be a much simpler approach, but need to know exact requirements to confirm.

I am not aware of a full detailed requirements document - depending on the problem area you are interested in, I guess the papers are the best source of public information. There will also be a journal article summarising the solution we came up with in MANDAT but the requirements are rather high-level in there. Will drop it here anyways when it is available.

What area are you thinking of in particular?
Just a way to satisfy requirements that is simpler.  Simple is great for scale.
Well, what area of requirements are you talking about? I am curious.
Authorization? Delegation? Data Provision Chains?

The requirements from a real world legal point of view - (nothing at all about the tech like auth/delegation/data provision) just the actual legal requirements for the bank / smb / tax use case you showed

uvdsl (Christoph Braun) is it the exact same scenario?

- https://github.com/DATEV-Research/Solid-B2B-showcase
- https://ceur-ws.org/Vol-3759/paper10.pdf

elf-pavlik (elf Pavlik): Yes, these are the same. The latter illustration is outdated; it was an early visualisation of the flow / an early version. We never updated that in the repo. What is actually different in particular, is that the tax advisor actually stores the data in their Pod and that then the SME dynamically fetches that data. As seen in the former illustration (Figure 2).

Well, I do not recall the exact paragraphs but the general requirements as communicated by our partners were along the lines of:

- relationship between SME and TAO must not be revealed (unless SME chooses to)
- relationship between employee and organisation should not be revealed (if not necessary (it is not necessary) or unless the employee chooses to)
- tracing of activities, there must be documentation at the organisation that shows who was granted access by whom when and when did access occur, when were actions triggered by the employee to be then executed on behalf of the company, were they actually executed or declined to be executed, ... (and so on)
- and some more, which I do not recall of the top of my head but should (TM) be documented in the papers.

Also, keep in mind, that we wanted to build on the decentralised nature of the Web - not relying on a central facilitator (even though DATEV might be in / take such a role).
From the outside of a company (e.g. consider the first image, "Figure 2", posted by pavlik above) only Solid-compliant APIs are exposed / necessary. To join such an ecosystem, the internal components (RDP, DPP, ...) are not strictly required. Organisations can choose to solve the corresponding problems differently. Only a Solid-compliant API - e.g. the Pod (or DPP) - needs to be exposed.

I'd be interested in what you think would pose a simple solution.
I am confused by the line "frontend - backend" ... if "backend" means internal, then I have no idea how do peers engage ...

No, backend does not necessarily mean internal / not exposed. It just means that these components are server-side components while the frontend are browser-based apps (we just used SPAs for simplicity in the project.). How exactly the backend components are configured to be exposed is open to configuration, we basically chose the let the DPP wrap the Pod, exposing the usual Solid API. RDP could e.g. only accept HTTP requests from organisational IP addresses. (In our project, it is also exposed as it is a usual Solid API and access was only granted to the corresponding organisation's employees) - but again these things can be solved differently - as long as there is a Solid compliant API, and to be fair, a description what container expects what data, similar to SAI.

I see potential issues (or unanswered questions?) of scalability, synchronicity, traceability and security/trust in those backend connections - mostly in the identity side, but some in the entitlement side.

title: Solid App Discoverability and Status
summary: Users inquired about Solid apps not listed on the outdated apps page, leading to a confirmation that app listing efforts are transitioning to the new Solid Catalog and a clarification on the status of the sleepy.bike instance.

messages.body: Are there any Solid apps that currently work with solidcommunity.net but that are not listed on https://solidproject.org/apps ?
I noticed sleepy.bike is not listed, but I also could not get it to work with solidcommunity.net currently. Maybe I'm doing something wrong or the service is temporarily down?
Any other apps I should try out?

Sleepy.bike [Community Solid Pod](https://community.sleepy.bike) (member list) has been down since January. I don't control the domain and no longer have github access to update the instance. I turned the infrastructure off in January after 5 months notice. The app hosted by github pages remains. The state is very unfortunate.

There are other instances (tired.bike, folks.solidcouch.org) that I develop and maintain, feel free to try them (your sleepy.bike profile data should be compatible); but I wouldn't recommend listing them at the moment as it's a contentious topic.

Both better error reporting, and the community survival of a central point of failure are TODO.

The solidproject.org apps page has not been maintained in a long time.  Work on listing apps has moved to https://catalog.solidproject.org/.  The catalog is currently in a period of trying to get updates on all projects and once that process is complete, the solidproject.org apps page will be replaced.  I  donb't know anything about the current state of sleepy.bike.  I do know that tired.couch is alive and well and was presented by @mrkvon:matrix.org  at the Solid symposium, see https://sosy2025.pages.dev/solid-together/ towards the bottom of the page.

title: Discussion on Binary RDF Formats (HDT, CBOR-LD) and Performance
summary: Members share resources on binary RDF formats like Jelly RDF, HDT, and CBOR-LD, discussing historical usage, performance issues, and potential solutions like streaming protocols.

messages.body: maybe useful for someone: https://jelly-rdf.github.io/dev/
also maybe useful for someone: https://www.rdfhdt.org/
I recall this blog post published over a decade ago https://ruben.verborgh.org/blog/2014/09/30/bringing-fast-triples-to-nodejs-with-hdt/

There is also https://w3c.github.io/json-ld-cbor/
I bet niko at NextGraph.org has some insights on various binary formats for RDF
https://www.w3.org/TR/rdf-canon/
https://json-ld.github.io/cbor-ld-spec/
Someone's company has tried to use this in the past, and their only statement was "Takes ages to compute".

I didn't know about Ruben's work.  Thanks! :-)  I wrote an HDT reader in Javascript way back then, using it as an experimental streaming protocol over WebSockets.  I found it a bit more efficient than compressed n-triples as I could directly read the HDT payload on the client.  Binary RDF is a area of interest of mine.  Happy to talk shop on it anytime :D
I would imagine so when the BitmapTriples form is used as indexes are created to facilitate fast searching.  I wonder if they tried the TriplesList version which would work better for streaming.
I don't know the details - they do have an enterprise-level knowledge graph built on triples ...

title: Addressing Security and Loop Prevention in Social Queries
summary: Josh Cornejo raises detailed questions regarding network security (DDoS) and loop prevention in decentralized social queries, which Niko addresses by detailing unique query IDs and asynchronous forwarding logic.

messages.body:
On the social query:

- how do you protect from DDos ?
- What is I want "partial" trust (e.g. "I want to answer questions about jobs, but not about dating?")
actually a 3rd: how do you protect from "infinite loops" and "hammering Kevin Bacon" (apparently after 6 degrees, everyone is connected to Kevin)

> <@josh-cornejo:matrix.org> actually a 3rd: how do you protect from "infinite loops" and "hammering Kevin Bacon" (apparently after 6 degrees, everyone is connected to Kevin)

both cases are answered with a simple mechanism: each participant in a social query keeps track of the unique identifier of that query, and will not answer twice to it.
but that doesn't stop the possibility of network overflow and the message reaching that 'layer' ?
There's no way Kevin Bacon's phone will handle 'discards'
(or maybe the phone never gets it, but the network will overflow?)

> <@josh-cornejo:matrix.org> On the social query:
> 
> - how do you protect from DDos ?
> - What is I want "partial" trust (e.g. "I want to answer questions about jobs, but not about dating?")

DDOS : you can only send query requests to the inbox of someone you know.
the inbox has a random ID of 32 bytes.

and only registered users can contact their home broker to do so.

the only attack surface is the login mechanism on the broker. it concerns all API calls, not only social queries.
it will be defended by classical means ( fail2ban ). and also with https://github.com/mCaptcha/mCaptcha

> <@josh-cornejo:matrix.org> (or maybe the phone never gets it, but the network will overflow?)

the phone or device will not get any spam message as the inbox IF is unknowable to the attacker

> <@josh-cornejo:matrix.org> On the social query:
> 
> - how do you protect from DDos ?
> - What is I want "partial" trust (e.g. "I want to answer questions about jobs, but not about dating?")

partial trust is handled easily with access control. when user receives a social query that doesnt have permission yet for remote user to use the needed data, then a notification asks for such permission, that can be restricted by resource class and storage location

I see that the potential DDoS could be at network level, not app level (all my 300 contacts would send me a message ... and to all people in their contact list, but we will "forward" only once ... although not sure how i determine that I don't need to send it back to everyone that sent it to me as now I need to keep track of who from the 300 sent it, and which didn't?)
we only receive requests from trusted users who are in our contact list
Yes
I get that
we forward to everyone we know, but they might not answer to us, if tgey already answered the same query via someone else in the social network
But in simple terms: i have 3 friends ... i get 2 messages and should only forward to the 1 person that didn't send it to me, so the app needs to track who sent it?

i never forward to the users who sent me a request. but in the case you mention, if we call them A B and C, when i receive the request from A i forward to B and C. when B receives it, it doesn't send it back to me. if you are talking about a race condition where B sends the same request to me cincurrently wirh A, then it could be that i send the message to A and B. they will only answer it once, so all is good
once across all the social network.

I think it is more of a potential overflow if it is not concurrent (e.g. A sends the message at 10am / B at 11 am ...) ... I suppose you could use ULID's for time sequencing and maybe TTL are included (e.g. 30 min)

the case you mention is the concurrent case. everything is asynchronous, we do not take into account timing.
A and B sends me the same request, then i will only answer to the first one
and will forward it to everyone except the one i just received it from
so when i receive it from A, i will forward to B. and 1 hour later, when i receive it from B, i will not forward it to anyone, because i already did that.
B must have been offline, and will not process the request i send it. when B gets online again, it will discard my request because it surely already processed it

title: Anytype, Local-First, and Generic vs. Specialized App Strategy
summary: The discussion focuses on the 'everything app' Anytype, contrasting it with the philosophy of specialized apps with strong interop, a gap that PodOS aims to address.

messages.body: Just seen this on a post - https://anytype.io

Nice, it seems like quite a lot of people are working on it. Personally I have strong preference for everyone to be able to cherry pick specialized apps for different specific task and have robust app interop in place, still great to see them exploring *the everything app* idea.

I am using anytype for quite a while now and it is really cool, but the core problem as you say [@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im](https://matrix.to/#/@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im) is that you have to decide whether to use a generic app like this OR specialized apps. I am trying to close this gap with PodOS
Meredith (CEO from Signal) describes the ultimate use case - https://youtu.be/jY8cd2YMdI4?si=Jv5fFa65dyEXxpEB

> <@josh-cornejo:matrix.org> Just seen this on a post - https://anytype.io

Anytype is awesome, Iâ€™ve been using it for a while. Itâ€™s been a great experience

title: Repository Branch Cleanup and Creation of Dedicated Catalog Management Channel
summary: A discussion on cleaning up merged branches in the `solid/catalog` repository leads to a decision to move detailed repo maintenance discussions into a newly created dedicated chat room.

messages.body: Jeff Zucker (he/him), jeswr (Jesse Wright): Can we delete any of those branches? https://github.com/solid/catalog/branches
AFAIK, yes. Under what circumstances might it be advisable to keep a branch?
When you are still working on it
Okay, so once stuff is committed from it, delete it.
Could you delete branches your created, this way you can double check if everything made its way into `main`.
Deleted all of mine
How can I do that double check?
Looking at related PR should be enough. I usually delete branch right after merging the PR, in most cases github does it automatically.
jeswr (Jesse Wright): could you please remind us how what was the strategy for https://github.com/solid/catalog/tree/next ?
Should we maybe create a 3-way chat for these kinds of discussion to not crowd the Practitioner's channel?

Currently CONTRIBUTING links here https://github.com/solid/catalog/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#questions-and-discussion
We could also create solid/catalog if we want to have a dedicated channel, I would prefer not to have a 3-way chat for that.
This room seems like an appropriate place to discuss general issues about the catalog. It is not an appropriate place to discuss details of maintaining the repo.

I have created the room https://matrix.to/#/#solid_catalog:matrix.org for discussions of project/repo management of the catalog.  @elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im - for some reason it won't let me invite you to the room so please join it.

title: Introduction of Valueflows Community Members and Project Scope
summary: Elf Pavlik introduces Lynn Foster (Valueflows), sparking a discussion about the project's resonance with Solid use cases like ERP and food networks, and welcoming new members.

messages.body:
I invited lynnfoster who works on https://www.valueflo.ws/ with strong emphasis on putting it in practice. A small example (there are more) https://youtu.be/DlnaWGtIsBQ
Some more related links http://mikorizal.org/links.html
She would be also interested in joinining the meeting when Tom Byrd will present his work on food networks in US.
https://youtu.be/CUlzhvwSJYM

Thanks @elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im and welcome @lynnfoster:matrix.org!  It would be great to have you present.  Tom will probably present on Sept. 18.  You can present either on Aug.  7 (though I need to check with co-chairs, that may already be booked) or on Sept. 4.  If you can't make either of those message me and we'll work something out.

Thanks Jeff Zucker (he/him) !  I don't know that I need to present particularly, although I'm happy to if people are interested related to any specific use case.  But I'll probably need to lurk a bit to get a feel for the work and the process.  And I haven't worked in Solid, although I've followed elf-pavlik (elf Pavlik) along that journey from a distance for awhile, and probably know a couple other people here.  I came in because someone ran into this project https://solid.github.io/erp/, and noticed the resonance with Valueflows, and pinged Pavlik and Michiel de Jong (Ponder Source) in the Valueflows channel.  Pavlik put a *lot* of work into Valueflows in the early years.  Both ERP and Food were important use case inputs to Valueflows.  And a few years ago, we did some data mapping with DFC.  Anyhow, I'd be interested in hearing what Tom Byrd has to say on Sept 18.  And I'm happy to be here and get more acquainted!
Maxime Lecoq-Gaillard (lecoqlibre): It would be great if you could join Tom's presentation as well, I'm curious how does it relate to DFC work.

Lurkers are always welcome ðŸ˜.  We often feature projects outside of Solid as we are more interested in learning ways that software can be useful in the world and Solid isn't the only project exploring that question.

Welcome Jon!  We encourage everyone to participate to the extent they want to and that includes lurking.  We do invite everyone to introduce themselves and their interests/projects at meetings but "Hi I'm Jon" is totally fine if that's all you want to share at the time.  @lynnfoster:matrix.org please take your time in acclimating to the group but also be aware that when we say "present at a meeting" we aren't necessarily talking about any kind of formal presentation.  The purpose of our group is to share knowledge with each other, to learn about and help each other with our projects.  So some presentations are full demos of working projects and some are just a description of the project and a brainstorming session about similar projects or particular issues the project faces.

Hey Jeff!

I had been involved in the SolidBase budgeting application based on the VF ontology by Lynn et al.

The project ceded from the web and all Solid app lists, but my interest to learn about ongoing activities in the Solid community remains.

For now I need to watch the conversation for a while, before I can contribute much. Hope that's okay (:

It's absolutely okay to watch.  There is no specific  technical knowledge or background required.  The Practitioners Group is for all to learn and learning doesn't always involve talking.  Contributions of any kind are always welcome but please take all the time you need to figure out what you want to contribute.

title: Planning Practitioners Session on Food Scarcity and Short Supply Chains
summary: Jeff and Lynn planned a session for the September 18th Practitioners meeting focusing on food scarcity, food distribution, and short supply chains, featuring Valueflows as a potential presentation topic.

messages.body: @lynnfoster:matrix.org I have tentatively chosen our 18 September meeting to have a session on food scarcity, food distribution, and short supply chains.  I am inviting Maxime Lecoq from the Data Food Consortium, and Tom Byrd from the Baltimore Food Project to present and hereby invite you to either present or simply attend if you prefer.  Does that date work for you?  If not, does the first or third Thursday in October work for you?

I am almost positive Sept 18 works. I'll know for sure later in August, but I think it's good to go ahead with it.  I can present or listen.  If I present, I could be a shorter add-on to the others, since Valueflows isn't specific to food.  Although I can demo a short supply chain.
As I understand it, projects dealing with food scarcity often involve short supply chain whether that applies to local farm produce or food banks redistributing food.
That makes sense.  And we could probably all benefit from a short supply chain for food, local is good for fresh food. :)
Yes, especially in inner-city areas where grocery options are limited and are not a prime location for  organic/health food stores serving more privileged areas.
Anyhow, I'll block out my calendar.  What time are these events?
And do you do them regularly twice a month?
15:00 UTC/GMT the first and third Thursdays of every month except for July and August during which we only meet on the first Thursday.
Thanks!

title: Feedback on Solid Developer Experience and Documentation Quality
summary: Lukedary shared positive progress from a development day but criticized the poor quality and outdated state of official Solid documentation, especially from Inrupt, while praising community resources.

messages.body: Had what we call a "Red Hack Day" today. Scraped together a loose demo that at least included login and retrieval of user profile data. A lot of learning on my part, but also proof to me of how great the potential for Solid is. Biggest gripe is the same as for most of my undertakings lately: Node has mostly maimed native development for the browser. The other thing that was hard is finding good/current documentation that doesn't 404 frequently. The Inrupt content was a frequent letdown in both regards  https://github.com/ewingson/solid-info was a godsend though to get over the biggest bumps.
@ewingson:matrix.org ^^

title: Adoption and Maturity Debate
summary: Lukedary sought advice on selling Solid's data sovereignty benefit internally against existing centralized solutions, which sparked a debate between Jeff and Elf-pavlik regarding whether Solid should be characterized as an 'alpha test period' or a practical platform for applications today.

messages.body: Thought this group might be a good one to have thoughts or experience that I could pass along for my ongoing saga of trying to convince/sell folks internally on using Solid. Last week I sent an impassioned recommendation to our senior leadership to read "This is for Everyone", and to consider Solid. Today an assortment of people (no senior leadership) had a meeting with a group that is leveraging Snowflake (Dataverse?) as an aggregator for user data from a variety of sources (training, Adobe, events, etc.). The issue I'm running up against is that we've already got auth using Keycloak or IBM Verify, and now this snowflake piece could apparently handle CRUD operations. How do I get people over what seems like the insurmountable hurdle of wanting to give users their data sovereignty when faced with other solutions that, on the surface, appear to achieve the same functionality? I'm not a good salesperson.

Since you mentioned Keycloak, there was an ongoing work for adding Solid-OIDC support: https://github.com/CarrettiPro/keycloak-solid. I used to have it listed in Solid Efforts. I will need to add it back.
In general, I would be cautious to always be clear that Solid is still a moving target. Currently, it is based on a set of Solid CG drafts, some providing alternatives to one another, and various work happening outside of the CG, which is also part of the broader Solid Ecosystem. The first cornerstone of solid will be the W3C LWS spec, which will be finalized in the best case a year from now. I would expect that the WG charter may need to be extended, and it may take even longer.    Meanwhile, implementation feedback is fundamental, so if people are in a position to aim for the long run and have the capacity to adjust to inevitable changes, then I would say try to help with making Solid happen. Personally, I see it as an alpha test period, where everyone needs to know that things are still work in progress, and while there is certain extra effort, it's also an opportunity to contribute to the final result in a meaningful way.

> I see it as an alpha test period

I think that statement, while perhaps true when looking solely at the specs, is completely misleading when it comes to user apps.  There are a number of apps which are either in production or are in beta or MVP phase.  It is perfectly feasable to make useful apps in the current state of affairs.  Will those apps need to be revised as the specs come into place, yes proabably.  But that does not meant that they can not perform the functions they were intended  for or be useful to people. This room and group are for people who are building those apps.  Please restrict your nay-saying to the specification channel which is what your critique applies to.  Yes, there are hurdles and things will change but that does not mean that nothing works or that users should be discouraged (as you are attempting to do).  I find it very counter-productive to meet new users with the kind of negativity you are displaying.  That is the way to scare off new users, not how to onboard them.

The question of adoption is really important and is definitely one that other practitioners are facing and that is an ongoing topic of discussion in our meetings.  This Thursday at 15:00 UTC we will be having a meeting to bring up general topics related to putting Solid into practice.  I invite you to come an open a discussion on the issue you raise and I'm sure others will be interested. The Open Data Institute (ODI), which provides stewardship for Solid is committed to working on issues of adoption so perhaps a discussion with the Solid lead for ODI @jeswr would help you.

Yeah, my view is proably on a gloomy side, mostly due to looking at things from perspective of fully open and interoperable ecosystem. If one wants to take step towards a semi-silo, where they have much more central control, than I can see that alredy much more can be done. I think we may need something in lines of [Richardson Maturity Model](https://martinfowler.com/articles/richardsonMaturityModel.html) which would help people to gradually adopt things, and possibly on specs writing side set priorities on lower levels.

Jeff, would you consider a small survey with following two questions appropriate to ask among Practicioners:
1. Explain why ODI's ESS instance has to use an allow-list for applications (come up with reasons yourself)
1. Compare risk for a user when on some random website they
  a) sign in with Google/GitHub/ etc
  b) sign in with Solid

The issue of ODI's support for ESS and community.net will definitely be a topic in the Practitioners.  Personally I feel that is better in a discussion format than a survey.   The question of how Solid handles login and security is an architectural question and therefore much more suited to the CG.  Practitioners tries to be bottom up - we start with a social issue or end-user need and work from there to practical ways those can be solved with Solid or other technologies.  Your top-down  approach - here's a technology/architecture question, how do we solve it is quite appropriate for the CG but unless one of our member projects is running into issues that they want addressed related to it, our discussions are focused on practice not theory, on things that exist or are being built today and can be used today to accomplish what our members are seeking to accomplish.  The Practitioners is meant to support people building products and services, not to discuss theories of how security should be handled which is much more appropriate for the CG.  If those topics come up in relation to a Practitioner project we'll certainly pass questions and suggestions to the CG, but I personally don't feel it is appropriate for the CG to raise those issues rather letting Practitioners decide for themselves what topics they want to discuss.

title: Discussion on Solid vs. Linked Web Storage (LWS)
summary: A user inquired about a rumored name change for Solid, leading to a discussion distinguishing 'Linked Web Storage' as the technical specification from 'Solid' as the preferred solution brand.

messages.body: So was talking with Solid contributor Jackson Morgan, and he told me the name is changing. I don't remember the new name he said would replace it, but I do remember not liking it. Anyone here know the new name?
Michael Munson: Maybe [Linked Web Storage](http://w3.org/groups/wg/lws/)?
I think that's it. Thanks.

I see that as a name for the tech, not a brand for the solution. Like, "open source software" is the type of thing and "Linux" is a specific open-source product. In this case, "Linked Wed Storage" is the type of thing, and Solid is a specific "LWS" solution.

oh wait could mean to use %20 ?
Which field in which form displayed this problem?  What was the error message?

It saved anyway. Don't worry about it.  For now just put "Jackson Morgan" as the maintainer, not an IRI, I will be replacing those fields with dropdowns soon.
